verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:1
verses.text: Sozomen, Book VI.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:2
verses.text: Chapter I.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:3
verses.text: —Expedition of Julian into Persia; he was worsted and broke off his Life Miserably.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:4
verses.text: Letter written by Libanius, describing his Death.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:5
verses.text: I have narrated in the preceding book the occurrences which took place in the Church, during the reign of Julian.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:6
verses.text: This emperor, having determined to carry on the war with Persia, made a rapid transit across the Euphrates in the beginning of spring, and, passing by Edessa from hatred to the inhabitants, who had long professed Christianity, he went on to Carrae, where there was a temple of Jupiter, in which he offered up sacrifice and prayer.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:7
verses.text: He then selected twenty thousand armed men from among his troops, and sent them towards the Tigris, in order that they might guard those regions, and also be ready to join him, in case he should require their assistance.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:8
verses.text: He then wrote to Arsacius, king of Armenia, one of the Roman allies, to bespeak his aid in the war.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:9
verses.text: In this letter Julian manifested the most unbounded arrogance; he boasted of the high qualities which had, he said, rendered him worthy of the empire, and acceptable to the gods for whom he cared; he reviled Constantius, his predecessor, as an effeminate and impious emperor, and threatened Arsacius in a grossly insulting way; and since he understood that he was a Christian, he intensified his insults, or eagerly and largely uttered unlawful blasphemies against Christ, for he was wont to dare this in every case.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:10
verses.text: He told Arsacius that unless he acted according to his directions, the God in whom he trusted would not be able to defend him from his vengeance.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:11
verses.text: When he considered that all his arrangements had been duly made, he led his army through Assyria.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:12
verses.text: He took a great many towns and fortresses, either through treachery or by battle, and thoughtlessly proceeded onwards, without reflecting that he would have to return by the same route.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:13
verses.text: He pillaged every place he approached, and pulled down or burnt the granaries and storehouses.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:14
verses.text: As he was journeying up the Euphrates, he arrived at Ctesiphon, a very large city, whither the Persian monarchs have now transferred their residence from Babylon.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:15
verses.text: The Tigris flows near this spot.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:16
verses.text: As he was prevented from reaching the city with his ships, by a part of the land which separated it from the river, he judged that either he must pursue his journey by water, or quit his ships and go to Ctesiphon by land; and he interrogated the prisoners on the subject.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:17
verses.text: Having ascertained from them that there was a canal which had been blocked up in the course of time, he caused it to be cleared out, and, having thus effected a communication between the Euphrates and the Tigris, he proceeded towards the city, his ships floating along by the side of his army.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:18
verses.text: But the Persians appeared on the banks of the Tigris with a formidable display of horse and many armed troops, of elephants, and of horses; and Julian became conscious that his army was besieged between two great rivers, and was in danger of perishing, either by remaining in its present position, or by retreating through the cities and villages which he had so utterly devastated that no provisions were attainable; therefore he summoned the soldiers to see horse-races, and proposed rewards to the fleetest racers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:19
verses.text: In the meantime he commanded the officers of the ships to throw over the provisions and baggage of the army, so that the soldiers, seeing themselves in danger by the want of necessaries, might turn about boldly and fight their enemies more desperately.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:20
verses.text: After supper he sent for the generals and tribunes and commanded the embarkation of the troops.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:21
verses.text: They sailed along the Tigris during the night and came at once to the opposite banks and disembarked; but their departure was perceived by some of the Persians, who exhorted one another to oppose them, but those still asleep the Romans readily overcame.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:22
verses.text: At daybreak, the two armies engaged in battle; and after much bloodshed on both sides, the Romans returned by the river, and encamped near Ctesiphon.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:23
verses.text: The emperor, being no longer desirous of proceeding further, burnt his vessels, as he considered that they required too many soldiers to guard them; and he then commenced his retreat along the Tigris, which was to his left.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:24
verses.text: The prisoners, who acted as guides to the Romans, led them to a fertile country where they found abundance of provisions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:25
verses.text: Soon after, an old man who had resolved to die for the liberty of Persia, allowed himself to be taken prisoner, and was brought before the emperor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:26
verses.text: On being questioned as to the route, and seeming to speak the truth, he persuaded them to follow him as capable of transporting the army very speedily to the Roman frontiers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:27
verses.text: He observed that for the space of three or four days' journey this road would be difficult, and that it would be necessary to carry provisions during that time, as the surrounding country was sterile.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:28
verses.text: The emperor was deceived by the discourse of this wise old man, and approved the march by this route.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:29
verses.text: On advancing further, after the lapse of three days, they were cast upon an uncultivated region.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:30
verses.text: The old prisoner was put to torture.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:31
verses.text: He confessed that he had exposed himself voluntarily to death for the sake of his country, and was therefore prepared to endure any sufferings that could be inflicted on him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:32
verses.text: The Roman troops were now worn out by the length of the journey and the scarcity of provisions, and the Persians chose this moment to attack them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:33
verses.text: In the heat of the conflict which ensued, a violent wind arose; and the sky and the sun were totally concealed by the clouds, while the air was at the same time mixed with dust.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:34
verses.text: During the darkness which was thus produced, a horseman, riding at full gallop, directed his lance against the emperor, and wounded him mortally.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:35
verses.text: After throwing Julian from his horse, the unknown assailant secretly went away.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:36
verses.text: Some conjectured that he was a Persian; others, that he was a Saracen.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:37
verses.text: There are those who insist that he who struck the blow was a Roman soldier, who was indignant at the imprudence and temerity which the emperor had manifested in exposing his army to such peril.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:38
verses.text: Libanius,  the sophist, a native of Syria, the most intimate friend of Julian, expressed himself in the following terms concerning the person who had committed the deed: "You desire to know by whom the emperor was slain.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:39
verses.text: I know not his name.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:40
verses.text: We have a proof, however, that the murderer was not one of the enemies; for no one came forward to claim the reward, although the king of Persia caused proclamation to be made, by a herald, of the honors to be awarded to him who had performed the deed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:41
verses.text: We are surely beholden to the enemy for not arrogating to themselves the glory of the action, but for leaving it to us to seek the slayer among ourselves.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:42
verses.text: "Those who sought his death were those who lived in habitual transgression of the laws, and who had formerly conspired against him, and who therefore perpetrated the deed as soon as they could find an opportunity.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 1:43
verses.text: They were impelled by the desire of obtaining a greater degree of freedom from all control than they could enjoy under his government; and they were, perhaps, mainly stimulated by their indignation at the attachment of the emperor to the service of the gods, to which they were averse".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:2
verses.text: —He perished under Divine Wrath.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:3
verses.text: Visions of the Emperor's Death seen by Various Individuals.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:4
verses.text: Reply of the Carpenter's Son; Julian tossed his Blood aloft to Christ.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:5
verses.text: Calamities which Julian entailed upon the Romans.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:6
verses.text: In the document above quoted, Libanius clearly states that the emperor fell by the hand of a Christian; and this, probably, was the truth.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:7
verses.text: It is not unlikely that some of the soldiers who then served in the Roman army might have conceived the idea, since Greeks and all men until this day have praised tyrannicides for exposing themselves to death in the cause of liberty, and spiritedly standing by their country, their families, and their friends.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:8
verses.text: Still less is he deserving of blame, who, for the sake of God and of religion, performed so bold a deed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:9
verses.text: Beyond this I know nothing accurately concerning the men who committed this murder besides what I have narrated.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:10
verses.text: All men, however, concur in receiving the account which has been handed down to us, and which evidences his death to have been the result of Divine wrath.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:11
verses.text: A proof of this is the Divine vision which one of his friends had, which I will now proceed to describe.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:12
verses.text: He had, it is related, traveled into Persia, with the intention of joining the emperor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:13
verses.text: While on the road, he found himself so far from any habitation that he was obliged, on one night, to sleep in a church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:14
verses.text: He saw, during that night, either in a dream or a vision, all the apostles and prophets assembled together, and complaining of the injuries which the emperor had inflicted on the Church, and consulting concerning the best measures to be adopted.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:15
verses.text: After much deliberation and embarrassment two individuals arose in the midst of the assembly, desired the others to be of good cheer, and left the company hastily, as if to deprive Julian of the imperial power.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:16
verses.text: He who was the spectator of this marvel did not attempt to pursue his journey, but awaited, in horrible suspense, the conclusion of this revelation.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:17
verses.text: He laid himself down to sleep again, in the same place, and again, he saw the same assembly; the two individuals who had appeared to depart the preceding night to effect their purpose against Julian, suddenly returned and announced his death to the others.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:18
verses.text: On the same day a vision was sent to Didymus, an ecclesiastical philosopher, who dwelt at Alexandria; and, who, being deeply grieved at the errors of Julian and his persecution of the churches, fasted and offered up supplications to God continually on this account.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:19
verses.text: From the effects of anxiety and want of food during the previous night, he fell asleep while sitting in his chair.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:20
verses.text: Then being, as it were, in an ecstasy, he beheld white horses traversing the air, and heard a voice saying to those who were riding thereon, "Go and tell Didymus that Julian has been slain just at this hour; let him communicate this intelligence to Athanasius, the bishop, and let him arise and eat".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:21
verses.text: I have been credibly informed that the friend of Julian and the philosopher beheld those things.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:22
verses.text: Results proved that neither of them were far from having witnessed the truth.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:23
verses.text: But if these instances do not suffice to prove that the death of Julian was the effect of Divine wrath on account of his persecution of the Church, let the prediction of one of the ecclesiastics be called to mind.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:24
verses.text: When Julian was preparing to enter upon the war against the Persians, he threatened that on the termination of the war he would treat the Christians with severity, and boasted that the Son of the Carpenter would be unable to aid them; the ecclesiastic above mentioned thereupon rejoined, that the Son of the Carpenter was then preparing him a wooden coffin in view of his death.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:25
verses.text: Julian himself was well aware whence the mortal stroke proceeded, and what was the cause of its infliction; for, it is said, when he was wounded, he took some of the blood that flowed from the wound, and threw it up into the air, as if he had seen Jesus Christ appearing, and intended to throw it at him, in order to reproach him with his slaughter.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:26
verses.text: Others say that he was angry with the sun because it had favored the Persians, and had not rescued him, although, according to the doctrine of the astronomers, it had presided at his birth; and that it was to express his indignation against this luminary that he took blood in his hand and flung it upwards in the air.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:27
verses.text: I know not whether, on the approach of death, as is wont to be the case when the soul is in the act of being separated from the body and when it is enabled to behold diviner spectacles than are allotted to men, and so Julian might have beheld Christ.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:28
verses.text: Few allusions have been made to this subject, and yet I dare not reject this hypothesis as absolutely false; for God often suffers still more improbable and astonishing events to take place in order to prove that the religion named after Christ is not sustained by human energy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:29
verses.text: It is, however, very obvious that, throughout the reign of this emperor, God gave manifest tokens of His displeasure, and permitted many calamities to befall several of the provinces of the Roman Empire.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:30
verses.text: He visited the earth with such fearful earthquakes, that the buildings were shaken, and no more safety could be found within the houses than in the open air.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:31
verses.text: From what I have heard, I conjecture that it was during the reign of this emperor, or, at least, when he occupied the second place in the government, that a great calamity occurred near Alexandria in Egypt,  when the sea receded and again passed beyond its boundaries from the reflux waves, and deluged a great deal of the land, so that on the retreat of the waters, the sea-skiffs were found lodged on the roofs of the houses.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:32
verses.text: The anniversary of this inundation, which they call the birthday of an earthquake, is still commemorated at Alexandria by a yearly festival; a general illumination is made throughout the city; they offer thankful prayers to God, and celebrate the day very brilliantly and piously.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:33
verses.text: An excessive drought also occurred during this reign; the plants perished and the air was corrupted; and for want of proper sustenance, men were obliged to have recourse to the food usually eaten by other animals.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:34
verses.text: The famine introduced peculiar diseases, by which many lives were lost.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 2:35
verses.text: Such was the state of the empire during the administration of Julian.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 3:2
verses.text: —The Reign of Jovian; he introduced Many Laws which he carried out in his Government.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 3:3
verses.text: After the decease of Julian, the government of the empire was, by the unanimous consent of the troops, tendered to Jovian.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 3:4
verses.text: When the army was about to proclaim him emperor, he announced himself to be a Christian and refused the sovereignty, nor would he receive the symbols of empire; but when the soldiers discovered the cause of his refusal, they loudly proclaimed that they were themselves Christians.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 3:5
verses.text: The dangerous and disturbed condition in which affairs had been left by Julian's strategy, and the sufferings of the army from famine in an enemy's country, compelled Jovian to conclude a peace with the Persians, and to cede to them some territories which had been formerly tributary to the Romans.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 3:6
verses.text: Having learned from experience that the impiety of his predecessor had excited the wrath of God, and given rise to public calamities, he wrote without delay to the governors of the provinces, directing that the people should assemble together without fear in the churches, that they should serve God with reverence, and that they should receive the Christian faith as the only true religion.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 3:7
verses.text: He restored to the churches and the clergy, to the widows and the virgins, the same immunities and every former dotation for the advantage and honor of religion, which had been granted by Constantine and his sons, and afterwards withdrawn by Julian.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 3:8
verses.text: He commanded Secundus,  who was then a praetorian prefect, to constitute it a capital crime to marry any of the holy virgins, or even to regard them with unchaste desires and to carry them off.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 3:9
verses.text: He enacted this law  on account of the wickedness which had prevailed during the reign of Julian; for many had taken wives from among the holy virgins, and, either by force or guile, had completely corrupted them; and thence had proceeded that indulgence of disgraceful lusts with impunity, which always occur when religion is abused.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:2
verses.text: —Troubles again arise in the Churches; Synod of Antioch, in which the Nicene Faith is confirmed; the Points which this Important Synod wrote about to Jovian.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:3
verses.text: The presidents of the churches now resumed the agitation of doctrinal questions and discussions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:4
verses.text: They had remained quiet during the reign of Julian when Christianity itself was endangered, and had unanimously offered up their supplications for the mercy of God.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:5
verses.text: It is thus that men, when attacked by foreign enemies, remain in accord among themselves; but, when external troubles are removed, then internal dissensions creep in; this, however, is not a proper place for the citation of the numerous examples in governments and nations which history affords of this fact.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:6
verses.text: At this period Basil, bishop of Ancyra, Silvanus, bishop of Tarsus, Sophronius, bishop of Pompeiopolis, and others of their party who regarded the heresy of the Anomians, so-called, with the utmost aversion, and received the term "similar as to substance," instead of the term "consubstantial," wrote a treatise to the emperor; and after expressing their thankfulness to God for his accession to the empire, besought him to confirm the decrees issued at Ariminum and Seleucia, and to annul what had been established merely by the zeal and power of certain individuals.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:7
verses.text: They also entreated that, if division, which existed on account of the Synods, should still prevail in the churches, the bishops from every region might be convened alone in some place indicated by the emperor, and not be permitted to assemble elsewhere and issue decrees at variance with each other, as had been done during the reign of Constantius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:8
verses.text: They added that they had not gone to visit him at his camp, because they were fearful of being burdensome to him; but that if he desired to see them, they would gladly repair to him, and defray all the expenses attendant on the journey themselves.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:9
verses.text: Such was the document written to the Emperor Jovian.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:10
verses.text: At this juncture a council was convened at Antioch in Syria; the form of belief established by the council of Nicaea was confirmed; and it was decided that the Son is incontrovertibly of the same substance as the Father.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:11
verses.text: Meletius, who then governed the church of Antioch; Eusebius, bishop of Samosata; Pelagius, bishop of Laodicea in Syria; Acacius, bishop of Caesarea in Palestine; Irenius, bishop of Gaza; and Athanasius, bishop of Ancyra, took part in this council.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:12
verses.text: On the termination of the council they acquainted the emperor with the transactions that had taken place, by dispatching the following letter:  —      "To the most religious and God-beloved Augustus, our Sovereign Jovian, the Conqueror, from the bishops assembled from divers regions, at Antioch.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:13
verses.text: "We know, O emperor, well-beloved of God, that your piety is fully intent upon maintaining peace and concord in the Church; neither are we ignorant that you have well received the impress of the chief point of such unity, viz.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:14
verses.text: , the true and orthodox faith.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:15
verses.text: "Lest, therefore, we should be reckoned among those who assail these doctrines of truth, we attest to your piety that we receive and maintain the form of belief which was anciently set forth by the holy council of Nicaea.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:16
verses.text: Now, although the term 'consubstantial' appears strange to some persons, yet it was safely interpreted by the Fathers, and signifies that the Son was begotten of the substance of the Father.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:17
verses.text: This term does not convey the idea of unbroken generation; neither does it coincide with the use which the Greeks make of the word 'substance,' but it is calculated to withstand the impious and rash allegation of Arius, that the Son proceeded from what had had no previous existence.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:18
verses.text: The Anomians who have just sprung up have the shameless boldness to maintain this word to the grief of the concord of the Church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:19
verses.text: We subjoin to this letter a copy of the formulary of faith adopted by the bishops assembled at Nicaea, which we also cherish".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 4:20
verses.text: Such were the decisions formed by the priests convened at Antioch; and they appended to their letter a copy of the Nicene formulary of faith.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:2
verses.text: —Athanasius the Great is Very Highly Esteemed by the Emperor, and rules over the Churches of Egypt.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:3
verses.text: Vision of Antony the Great.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:4
verses.text: At this period,  Athanasius, who governed the see of Alexandria, and some of his friends, deemed it requisite, as the emperor was a Christian, to repair to his court.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:5
verses.text: Accordingly Athanasius went to Antioch, and laid such matters before the emperor as he deemed expedient.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:6
verses.text: Others, however, say that the emperor sent for him in order to consult him concerning the affairs relative to religion and the right tenet.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:7
verses.text: When the business of the Church had as far as possible been transacted, Athanasius began to think of returning.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:8
verses.text: Euzoïus, bishop of the Arian heresy in Antioch, endeavored to install Probatius, a eunuch who held the same sentiments as himself, in Alexandria.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:9
verses.text: The whole party of Euzoïus conspired with him to effect this design; and Lucius, a citizen of Alexandria, who had been ordained presbyter by George, endeavored to prejudice the emperor against Athanasius, by representing  that he had been accused of divers crimes and had been condemned to perpetual banishment by preceding emperors, as the author of the dissensions and troubles of the Church concerning the Divine Being.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:10
verses.text: Lucius likewise besought Jovian to appoint another bishop over the church of Alexandria.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:11
verses.text: The emperor, since he knew the plots which had happened against Athanasius, attached no credit to the calumny, and with threatening, commanded Lucius to retire quietly; he also ordered Probatius and the other eunuchs belonging to his palace, whom he regarded as the originators of these troubles, to act more advisedly.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:12
verses.text: From that period Jovian manifested the greatest friendship towards Athanasius, and sent him back to Egypt, with directions to govern the churches and people of that country as he might think fit.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:13
verses.text: It is also said that he passed commendations on the virtue of the bishop, on his life, his intellectual endowments, and his eloquence.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:14
verses.text: Thus, after having been exposed to opposition for a long while, as has been narrated in the former books, was the Nicene faith fully reestablished under the present government; but further embarrassment awaited it within a very short period.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:15
verses.text: For, as it appeared afterwards, the whole of the prediction of Antony the Monk was not fulfilled by the occurrences which befell the Church during the reign of Constantius; part thereof was not accomplished until the reign of Valens.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:16
verses.text: It is said that before the Arians got control of the churches during the reign of Constantius, Antony had a dream in which he saw mules kicking the altar with their hoofs and overturning the holy table.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:17
verses.text: On awakening, he immediately predicted that the Church would be troubled by the introduction of spurious and mixed doctrines, and by the rebellion of the heterodox.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 5:18
verses.text: The truth of this prediction was evidenced by the events which occurred before and after the period now under review.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:2
verses.text: —Death of Jovian; The Life of Valentinian, and his Confidence in God; how he was advanced to the Throne and selected his Brother Valens to reign with him; the Differences of Both.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:3
verses.text: After Jovian had reigned about eight months, he died suddenly at Dadastana, a town of Bithynia, while on his road to Constantinople.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:4
verses.text: Some say that his death was occasioned by eating too plentiful a supper; others attribute it to the dampness of the chamber in which he slept; for it had been recently plastered with unslaked lime, and quantities of coals had been burnt in it during the winter for a preventive; the walls had become damp and were exceedingly moist.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:5
verses.text: On the arrival of the troops at Nicaea in Bithynia, they proclaimed Valentinian emperor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:6
verses.text: He was a good man and capable of holding the reins of the empire.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:7
verses.text: He had not long returned from banishment; for it is said that Julian, immediately on his accession to the empire, erased the name of Valentinian from the Jovian legions, as they were called, and condemned him to perpetual banishment, under the pretext that he had failed in his duty of leading out the soldiers under his command against the enemy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:8
verses.text: The true reason of his condemnation, however, was the following: When Julian was in Gaul, he went one day to a temple to offer incense.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:9
verses.text: Valentinian  accompanied him, according to an ancient Roman law, which still prevails, and which enacted that the leader of the Jovians and the Herculeans (that is to say, the legions of soldiers who have received this appellation in honor of Jupiter and of Hercules) should always attend the emperor as his body-guard.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:10
verses.text: When they were about to enter the temple, the priest, in accordance with the pagan custom, sprinkled water upon them with the branch of a tree.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:11
verses.text: A drop fell upon the robe of Valentinian; he scarcely could restrain himself, for he was a Christian, and he rebuked his asperser; it is even said that he cut off, in view of the emperor, the portion of the garment on which the water had fallen, and flung it from him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:12
verses.text: From that moment Julian entertained inimical feelings against him, and soon after banished him to Melitine in Armenia, under the plea of misconduct in military affairs; for he would not have religion regarded as the cause of the decree, lest Valentinian should be accounted a martyr or a confessor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:13
verses.text: Julian treated other Christians, as we have already stated, in the same manner; for, as was said before, he perceived that to subject them to hazards only added to their reputation, and tended to the consolidation of their religion.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:14
verses.text: As soon as Jovian succeeded to the throne, Valentinian was recalled from banishment to Nicaea; but the death of the emperor in the meantime took place, and Valentinian, by the unanimous consent of the troops and those who held the chief positions in the government, was appointed his successor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:15
verses.text: When he was invested with the symbols of imperial power, the soldiers cried out that it was necessary to elect some one to share the burden of government.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:16
verses.text: To this proposition, Valentinian made the following reply: "It depended on you alone, O soldiers, to proclaim me emperor; but now that you have elected me, it depends not upon you, but upon me, to perform what you demand.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:17
verses.text: Remain quiet, as subjects ought to do, and leave me to act as an emperor in attending to the public affairs".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:18
verses.text: Not long after this refusal to comply with the demand of the soldiery, he repaired to Constantinople, and proclaimed his brother emperor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:19
verses.text: He gave him the East as his share of the empire, and reserved to himself the regions along the Western Ocean, from Illyria to the furthest coasts of Libya.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:20
verses.text: Both the brothers were Christians, but they differed in opinion and disposition.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:21
verses.text: For Valens, when he was baptized, employed Eudoxius as his initiator, and was zealously attached to the doctrines of Arius, and would readily have compelled all mankind by force to yield to them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 6:22
verses.text: Valentinian, on the other hand, maintained the faith of the council of Nicaea, and favored those who upheld the same sentiments, without molesting those who entertained other opinions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:2
verses.text: —Troubles again arise in the Churches, and the Synod of Lampsacus is held.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:3
verses.text: The Arians who supported Eudoxius prevail and eject the Orthodox from the Churches.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:4
verses.text: Among the Ejected is Meletius of Antioch.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:5
verses.text: When Valentinian was journeying from Constantinople to Rome,  he had to pass through Thrace; and the bishops of Hellespontus and of Bithynia, with others, who maintained that the Son is consubstantial with the Father, dispatched Hypatian, bishop of Heraclea in Perinthus, to meet him, and to request permission to assemble themselves together for deliberation on questions of doctrine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:6
verses.text: When Hypatian had delivered the message with which he was intrusted, Valentinian made the following reply: "I am but one of the laity, and have therefore no right to interfere in these transactions; let the priests, to whom such matters appertain, assemble where they please".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:7
verses.text: On receiving this answer through Hypatian, their deputy, the bishops assembled at Lampsacus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:8
verses.text: After having conferred together for the space of two months, they annulled all that had been decreed at Constantinople, through the machinations of the partisans of Eudoxius and Acacius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:9
verses.text: They likewise declared null and void the formulary of faith which had been circulated under the false assertion that it was the compilation of the Western bishops, and to which the signatures of many bishops had been obtained, by the promise that the dogma of dissimilarity as to substance should be condemned,—a promise which had never been performed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:10
verses.text: They decreed that the doctrine of the Son being in substance like unto the Father, should have the ascendancy; for they said that it was necessary to resort to the use of the term "like" as indicative of the hypostases of the Godhead.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:11
verses.text: They agreed that the form of belief which had been confessed at Seleucia, and set forth at the dedication of the church of Antioch, should be maintained by all the churches.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:12
verses.text: They directed that all the bishops who had been deposed by those who hold that the Son is dissimilar from the Father, should forthwith be reinstated in their sees, as having been unjustly ejected from their churches.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:13
verses.text: They declared that if any wished to bring accusations against them, they would be permitted to do so, but under the penalty of incurring the same punishment as that due to the alleged crime, should the accusation prove to be false.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:14
verses.text: The orthodox bishops of the province and of the neighboring countries were to preside as judges, and to assemble in the church, with the witnesses who were to make the depositions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:15
verses.text: After making these decisions, the bishops summoned the partisans of Eudoxius, and exhorted them to repentance; but as they would give no heed to these remonstrances, the decrees enacted by the council were sent to all the churches.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:16
verses.text: Judging that Eudoxius would be likely to endeavor to persuade the emperor to side with him, and would calumniate them, they determined to be beforehand with him, and to send an account of their proceedings in Lampsacus to the court.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:17
verses.text: Their deputies met the Emperor Valens as he was returning from Heraclea to Thrace, where he had been traveling in company with his brother, who had gone on to Old Rome.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:18
verses.text: Eudoxius, however, had previously gained over the emperor and his courtiers to his own sentiments; so that when the deputies of the council of Lampsacus presented themselves before Valens, he merely exhorted them not to be at variance with Eudoxius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:19
verses.text: The deputies replied by reminding him of the artifices to which Eudoxius had resorted at Constantinople, and of his machinations to annul the decrees of the council of Seleucia; and these representations kindled the wrath of Valens to such a pitch, that he condemned the deputies to banishment, and made over the churches to the partisans of Eudoxius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:20
verses.text: He then passed over into Syria, for he feared lest the Persians should break the truce which they had concluded with Jovian for thirty years.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:21
verses.text: On finding, however, that the Persians were not disposed to insurrection, he fixed his residence at Antioch.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:22
verses.text: He sent Meletius, the bishop, into banishment, but spared Paul, because he admired the sanctity of his life.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 7:23
verses.text: Those who were not in communion with Euzoïus were either ejected from the churches, or maltreated and harassed in some other form.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:2
verses.text: —Revolt and Extraordinary Death of Procopius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:3
verses.text: Eleusius, Bishop of Cyzicus, and Eunomius, the Heretic.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:4
verses.text: Eunomius succeeds Eleusius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:5
verses.text: It is probable that a severe persecution might have ensued at this juncture, had not Procopius commenced a civil war.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:6
verses.text: As he began to play the tyrant at Constantinople, he soon collected a large army, and marched against Valens.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:7
verses.text: The latter quitted Syria, and met Procopius near Nacolia, a city of Phrygia, and captured him alive through the treachery of Agelon and Gomarius, two of his generals.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:8
verses.text: Valens put him and his betrayers to a cruel death; and although it is said that he had sworn to show favor to the two generals, he caused them to be sawn asunder.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:9
verses.text: He commanded Procopius to be fastened by the legs to two trees which had been bent to the ground, and he allowed these to spring up; when the trees were left to resume their natural position, the victim was torn in twain.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:10
verses.text: On the termination of this war, Valens retired to Nicaea, and finding himself in possession of profound tranquillity, he again began to molest those who differed from him in opinion concerning the Divine nature.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:11
verses.text: His anger was unbounded against the bishops of the council of Lampsacus, because they had condemned the Arian bishops and the formulary of faith set forth at Ariminum.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:12
verses.text: While under the influence of these resentful feelings, he summoned Eleusius from Syria, and having called together a Synod of bishops who held his own sentiments, he endeavored to compel him to assent to their doctrines.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:13
verses.text: Eleusius at first manfully refused compliance.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:14
verses.text: But afterwards, from the dread of exile and deprivation of his property, as was threatened by the emperor, he yielded to the mandate.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:15
verses.text: He soon repented of his weakness, and on his return to Cyzicus he made a public confession of his fault in the church, and urged the people to choose another bishop, for he said that he could not discharge the duties of a priesthood after having been a traitor to his own doctrine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:16
verses.text: The citizens respected his conduct and were especially well-disposed to him, so that they did not choose to have another bishop.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:17
verses.text: Eudoxius, president of the Arians in Constantinople, however, ordained Eunomius as bishop of Cyzicus; for he expected that by his great powers of eloquence Eunomius would easily draw the people of Cyzicus over to his own sentiments.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:18
verses.text: On his arrival at that city he expelled Eleusius, for he was furnished with an imperial edict to that effect, and took possession of the churches himself.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:19
verses.text: The followers of Eleusius built a house of prayer without the walls of the city, and here they held their assemblies.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 8:20
verses.text: I shall soon again have occasion to revert to Eunomius and the heresy which bears his name.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 9:2
verses.text: —Sufferings of those who maintained the Nicene Faith.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 9:3
verses.text: Agelius, the Ruler of the Novatians.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 9:4
verses.text: The Christians who represented the Nicene doctrines and the followers of the Novatian views  were treated with equal severity in the city of Constantinople.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 9:5
verses.text: They were all ultimately expelled from the city; and the churches of the Novatians were closed by order of the emperor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 9:6
verses.text: The other party had no churches to be closed, having been deprived of them all during the reign of Constantius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 9:7
verses.text: At this period, Agelius who, from the time of Constantius, had governed the church of the Novatians at Constantinople, was condemned to banishment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 9:8
verses.text: It is said that he was especially remarkable for his course of life according to the ecclesiastical laws.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 9:9
verses.text: With respect to his mode of life, he had attained to the highest degree of philosophy, namely, freedom from worldly possessions; this was evidenced by his daily conduct; he had but one tunic, and always walked barefooted.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 9:10
verses.text: Not long after his banishment, he was recalled, received the churches under him, and boldly convened churches through the influence of Marcian, a man of extraordinary virtue and eloquence, who had formerly been enrolled among the troops of the palace, but at this period was a presbyter of the Novatian heresy, and the teacher of grammar to Anastasia and Carosa,  the daughters of the emperor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 9:11
verses.text: There are still baths at Constantinople which bear the names of these princesses.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 9:12
verses.text: It was for the sake of Marcian alone that the privilege above-mentioned was conceded to the Novatians.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:2
verses.text: —Concerning Valentinian the Younger and Gratian.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:3
verses.text: Persecution under Valens.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:4
verses.text: The Homoousians, being oppressed by the Arians and Macedonians, send an Embassy to Rome.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:5
verses.text: About this period, a son was born to Valentinian in the West, to whom the emperor gave his own name.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:6
verses.text: Not long after, he proclaimed his son Gratian emperor; this prince was born before his father held the government.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:7
verses.text: In the meantime, although hailstones of extraordinary magnitude fell in various places, and although many cities, particularly Nicaea in Bithynia, were shaken by earthquakes, yet Valens, the emperor, and Eudoxius, the bishop, paused not in their career, but continued to persecute all Christians who differed from them in opinion.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:8
verses.text: They succeeded to the utmost of their expectations in their machinations against those who adhered to the Nicene doctrines; for throughout the greater time of Valens' rule, particularly in Thrace, Bithynia, and the Hellespont, and still further beyond, these Christians had neither churches nor priests.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:9
verses.text: Valens and Eudoxius then directed their resentment against the Macedonians, who were more in number than the Christians above mentioned in that region, and persecuted them without measure.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:10
verses.text: The Macedonians, in apprehension of further sufferings, sent deputies to various cities, and finally agreed to have recourse to Valentinian and to the bishop of Rome rather than share in the faith of Eudoxius and Valens and their followers; and when this seemed favorable for execution, they selected three of their own number,—Eustathius, bishop of Sebaste; Silvanus, bishop of Tarsus; and Theophilus, bishop of Castabalis,—and sent them to the Emperor Valentinian; they likewise intrusted them with a letter, addressed to Liberius, bishop of Rome, and to the other priests of the West, in which they entreated them as prelates who had adhered to the faith approved and confirmed by the apostles, and who before others ought to watch over religion, to receive their deputies with all confirmation, and to confer with them about what should be done in the interval until the affairs of the Church could be approvedly set in order.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:11
verses.text: When the deputies arrived in Italy, they found that the emperor was in Gaul, engaged in war against the barbarians.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:12
verses.text: As they considered that it would be perilous to visit the seat of war in Gaul, they delivered their letter to Liberius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:13
verses.text: After having conferred with him concerning the objects of their embassy, they condemned Arius and those who held and taught his doctrines; they renounced all heresies opposed to the faith established at Nicaea; and received the term "consubstantial," as being a word that conveys the same signification as the expression "like in substance".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:14
verses.text: When they had presented a confession of faith, analogous to the above, to Liberius, he received them into communion with himself, and wrote to the bishops of the East, commending the orthodoxy of their faith, and detailing what had passed in the conference he had held with them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 10:15
verses.text: The confession of faith made by Eustathius and his companions was as follows:—.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 11:2
verses.text: —The Confession of Eustathius, Silvanus, and Theophilus, the Deputies of the Macedonians, to Liberius, Bishop of Rome.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 11:3
verses.text: "To Liberius, our Lord and Brother, and Fellow-minister—Eustathius, Silvanus, and Theophilus send greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 11:4
verses.text: "On account of the mad opinions of the heretics who do not cease to keep on sowing scandals for the Catholic churches, we who nullify their every attack confess the Synod which was held at Lampsacus, the one at Smyrna and the councils held in other places, by the orthodox bishops.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 11:5
verses.text: We have furnished letters and sent on an embassy to your Goodness, as likewise to all the other bishops of Italy and of the West, to confirm and preserve the Catholic faith, which was established at the holy council of Nicaea, by the blessed Constantine and three hundred and eighteen God-fearing fathers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 11:6
verses.text: "This remains, by an unmixed and immovable settlement, until now, and will remain perpetually; in which the term 'consubstantial' is fixed in all holiness and piety in testimony against the perverseness of Arius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 11:7
verses.text: We confess, each with his own hand, that we with the aforesaid have always held this same faith, that we still hold it, and that we shall adhere to it to the last.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 11:8
verses.text: We condemn Arius, his impious dogmas, and his disciples.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 11:9
verses.text: We also condemn the heresies of Patropasianus,  of Photinus, of Marcellus, of Paul of Samosata, and all who maintain such doctrines themselves.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 11:10
verses.text: We anathematize all heresies opposed to the aforesaid faith established by the saintly fathers at Nicaea.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 11:11
verses.text: We anathematize Arius especially, and condemn all such decrees as were enacted at Ariminum, in opposition to the aforesaid faith established by the holy council of Nicaea.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 11:12
verses.text: We were formerly deluded by the guile and perjury of certain parties, and subscribed to these decrees when they were transmitted to Constantinople from Nicaea, a city of Thrace".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 11:13
verses.text: After this confession they subjoined a copy of the entire formulary of Nicaea to their own creed, and, having received from Liberius a written account of all that they had transacted, they sailed to Sicily.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:2
verses.text: —Councils of Sicily and of Tyana.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:3
verses.text: The Synod which was expected to be held in Cilicia is dissolved by Valens.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:4
verses.text: The Persecution at that Time.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:5
verses.text: Athanasius the Great flees again, and is in Concealment; by the Letter of Valens he reappears, and governs the Churches in Egypt.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:6
verses.text: A council was convened at Sicily;  and after the same doctrines had been confirmed as those set forth in the confession of the deputies, the assembly was dissolved.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:7
verses.text: At the same time, a council was held at Tyana; and Eusebius, bishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia, Athanasius, bishop of Ancyra, Pelagius, bishop of Laodicea, Zeno, bishop of Tyre, Paul, bishop of Emesa, Otreus, bishop of Melitene, and Gregory, bishop of Nazianzen, were present with many others, who, during the reign of Jovian, had assembled at Antioch, and determined to maintain the doctrine of the Son being consubstantial with the Father.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:8
verses.text: The letters of Liberius and the Western bishops were read at this council.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:9
verses.text: These letters afforded high satisfaction to the members of the council; and they wrote to all the churches, desiring them to peruse the decrees of the bishops in Asia,  and the documents written by Liberius and the bishops of Italy, of Africa, of Gaul, and of Sicily, which had been intrusted to the deputies of the council of Lampsacus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:10
verses.text: They urged them to reflect on the great number of persons by whom these documents had been drawn up, and who were far more in number than the members of the council of Ariminum, and exhorted them to be of one mind, and to enter into communion with them, to signify the same by writing, and finally to assemble together at Tarsus in Cilicia before the end of the spring.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:11
verses.text: On a fixed date which they prescribed, they urged one another to convene.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:12
verses.text: On the approach of the appointed day, when the Synod was on the point of assembling at Tarsus, about thirty-four of the Asiatic bishops came together in Caria, in the province of Asia, commended the design of establishing uniformity of belief in the Church, but objected to the term "consubstantial," and insisted that the formularies of faith set forth by the councils of Antioch and Seleucia, and maintained by Lucian, the martyr, and by many of their predecessors, with dangers and tensions, ought to obtain the ascendancy over all others.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:13
verses.text: The emperor, at the instigation of Eudoxius, prevented by letter the council from being convened in Cilicia, and even prohibited it under severe penalties.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:14
verses.text: He also wrote to the governors of the provinces, commanding them to eject all bishops from their churches who had been banished by Constantine  and who had again taken up their priesthood under the Emperor Julian.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:15
verses.text: On account of this order, those who were at the head of the government of Egypt were anxious to deprive Athanasius of his bishopric and expel him from the city; for no light punishment was inserted in the imperial letters; for unless the injunctions were fulfilled, all the magistrates equally, and the soldiers under them, and counselors were condemned to the payment of much money and also threatened with bodily maltreatment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:16
verses.text: The majority of Christians of the city, however, assembled and besought the governor not to banish Athanasius without further consideration of the terms of the imperial letter, which merely specified all bishops who had been banished by Constantius and recalled by Julian; and it was manifest that Athanasius was not of this number, inasmuch as he had been recalled by Constantius and had resumed his bishopric; but Julian, at the very time that all the other bishops had been recalled, persecuted him, and finally Jovian recalled him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:17
verses.text: The governor was by no means convinced by these arguments; nevertheless, he restrained himself and did not give way to the use of force.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:18
verses.text: The people ran together from every quarter; there was much commotion and perturbation throughout the city; an insurrection was expected; he therefore advised the emperor of the facts and allowed the bishop to remain in the city.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:19
verses.text: Some days afterwards, when the popular excitement had seemingly abated, Athanasius secretly quitted the city at dusk, and concealed himself somewhere.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:20
verses.text: The very same night, the governor of Egypt and the military chief took possession of the church in which Athanasius generally dwelt, and sought him in every part of the edifice, and even on the roof, but in vain; for they had calculated upon seizing the moment when the popular commotion had partially subsided, and when the whole city was wrapt in sleep, to execute the mandate of the emperor, and to transport Athanasius quietly from the city.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:21
verses.text: Not to have found Athanasius naturally excited universal astonishment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:22
verses.text: Some attributed his escape to a special revelation from above; others to the advice of some of his followers; both had the same result; but more than human prudence seems to have been requisite to foresee and to avoid such a plot.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:23
verses.text: Some say, that as soon as the people gave indications of being disposed to sedition, he concealed himself among the tombs of his ancestors, being apprehensive lest he should be regarded as the cause of any disturbances that might ensue; and that he afterwards retreated to some other place of concealment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:24
verses.text: The Emperor Valens, soon after, wrote to grant permission for him to return and hold his church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:25
verses.text: It is very doubtful, whether, in making this concession, Valens acted according to his own inclination.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:26
verses.text: I rather imagine that, on reflecting on the esteem in which Athanasius was universally held, he feared to excite the displeasure of the Emperor Valentinian, who was well-known to be attached to the Nicene doctrines; or perhaps he was apprehensive of a commotion on the part of the many admirers of the bishop, lest some innovation might injure the public affairs.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:27
verses.text: I also believe that the Arian presidents did not, on this occasion, plead very vehemently against Athanasius; for they considered that, if he were ejected from the city, he would probably traduce them to the emperors and then would have an occasion for conference with respect to them, and might possibly succeed in persuading Valens to adopt his own sentiments, and in arousing the anger of the like-minded Valentinian against themselves.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:28
verses.text: They were greatly troubled by the evidences of the virtue and courage of Athanasius, which had been afforded by the events which had transpired during the reign of Constantius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:29
verses.text: He had, in fact, so skilfully evaded the plots of his enemies, that they had been constrained to consent to his reinstallation in the government of the churches of Egypt; and yet he could scarcely be induced to return from Italy, although letters had been dispatched by Constantius to that effect.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:30
verses.text: I am convinced that it was solely from these reasons that Athanasius was not expelled from his church like the other bishops, who were subjected to as cruel a persecution as ever was inflicted by pagans.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:31
verses.text: Those who would not change their doctrinal tenets were banished; their houses of prayer were taken from them, and placed in the possession of those who held opposite sentiments.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 12:32
verses.text: Egypt alone was, during the life of Athanasius, exempted from this persecution.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 13:2
verses.text: —Demophilus, an Arian, became Bishop of Constantinople after Eudoxius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 13:3
verses.text: The Pious elect Evagrius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 13:4
verses.text: Account of the Persecution which ensued.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 13:5
verses.text: About this time the Emperor Valens went to Antioch on the Orontes; while he was on his journey Eudoxius died, after having governed the churches of Constantinople during the space of eleven years.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 13:6
verses.text: Demophilus was immediately ordained as his successor by the Arian bishops.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 13:7
verses.text: The followers of the Nicene doctrines, believing that the course of events was in their power, elected Evagrius as their bishop.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 13:8
verses.text: He had been ordained by Eustathius, who had formerly governed the church of Antioch in Syria, and who having been recalled from banishment by Jovian, lived in a private manner at Constantinople, and devoted himself to the instruction of those who held his sentiments, exhorting them to perseverance in their view of the Divine Being.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 13:9
verses.text: The Arian heretics were stirred to revolt, and commenced a violent persecution against those who had participated in the ordination of Evagrius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 13:10
verses.text: The Emperor Valens, who was then at Nicomedia, on being apprised of the occurrences that had taken place in Constantinople since the death of Eudoxius, was fearful lest any interest of the city should suffer by sedition, and therefore sent thither as many troops as he thought requisite to preserve tranquillity.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 13:11
verses.text: Eustathius was arrested by his command and banished to Bizya, a city of Thrace, and Evagrius was exiled to some other region.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 13:12
verses.text: And such was the manner of this event.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 14:2
verses.text: —Account of the Eighty Pious Delegates in Nicomedia, whom Valens burned with the Vessel in Mid-Sea.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 14:3
verses.text: The Arians, as is customary with the prosperous, because more insolent,  persecuted unmercifully all Christians whose religious sentiments were opposed to their own.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 14:4
verses.text: These Christians being exposed to bodily injuries, and betrayed to magistrates and prisons, and finding themselves moreover gradually impoverished by the frequent fines, were at length compelled to appeal for redress to the emperor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 14:5
verses.text: Although exceedingly angry, the emperor did not openly manifest any wrath, but secretly commanded the prefect to seize and slay the whole deputation.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 14:6
verses.text: But the prefect, being apprehensive that a whole popular insurrection would be excited if he were to put so many good and religious men to death without any of the forms of justice, pretended that they were to be sent into exile, and under this pretext compelled them to embark on board a ship, to which they assented with the most perfect resignation.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 14:7
verses.text: When they had sailed to about the center of the bay, which was called Astacius, the sailors, according to the orders they had received, set fire to the vessel and leaped into the tender.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 14:8
verses.text: A wind arising, the ship was blown along to Dacibiza, a place on the sea-coast of Bithynia; but no sooner had it neared the shore, than it was utterly consumed with all the men on board.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 15:2
verses.text: —Disputes between Eusebius, Bishop of Caesarea, and Basil the Great.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 15:3
verses.text: Hence the Arians took courage and came to Caesarea, and were repulsed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 15:4
verses.text: When Valens quitted Nicomedia, he went on to Antioch;  and in passing through Cappadocia he did all in his power, according to custom, to injure the orthodox and to deliver up the churches to the Arians.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 15:5
verses.text: He thought to accomplish his designs the more easily on account of a dispute  which was then pending between Basil and Eusebius, who then governed the church of Caesarea.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 15:6
verses.text: This dissension had been the cause of Basil's departing from Pontus, where he lived conjointly with some monks who pursued the philosophy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 15:7
verses.text: The people and some of the most powerful and the wisest men in the city began to regard Eusebius with suspicion, particularly as they considered him the cause of the withdrawal of one who was equally celebrated for his piety and his eloquence; and they accordingly began to plan a secession and the holding of separate church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 15:8
verses.text: In the meantime Basil, fearing to be a source of further trouble to the Church, which was already rent by the dissensions of heretics, remained in retirement in the monasteries at Pontus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 15:9
verses.text: The emperor and the bishops of the Arian heresy, who were always attached to his suite, were more inspirited in their designs by the absence of Basil and the hatred of the people towards Eusebius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 15:10
verses.text: But the event was contrary to their judgment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 15:11
verses.text: On the first intelligence of the intention of the emperor to pass through Cappadocia, Basil quitted Pontus and returned to Caesarea, where he effected a reconciliation with Eusebius, and by his eloquence he opportunely aided the Church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 15:12
verses.text: The projects of Valens were thus defeated, and he returned with his bishops without having accomplished any of his designs.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:2
verses.text: —Basil becomes Bishop of Caesarea after Eusebius; his Boldness towards the Emperor and the Prefect.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:3
verses.text: Some time after, the emperor again visited Cappadocia, and found that Basil was administering the churches there after the death of Eusebius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:4
verses.text: He thought of expelling him, but was unwillingly restrained from his intention.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:5
verses.text: It is said that the night after he had formed his plans his wife was disturbed by a frightful dream, and that his only son Galates was cut off by a rapid disease.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:6
verses.text: The death of this son was universally attributed to the vengeance of God as a punishment of his parents for the machinations that had been carried on against Basil.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:7
verses.text: Valens himself was of this opinion, and, after the death of his son, offered no further molestation to the bishop.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:8
verses.text: When the prince was sinking under the disease, and at the point of death, the emperor sent for Basil and requested him to pray to God for his son's recovery.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:9
verses.text: For as soon as Valens had arrived at Caesarea, the prefect had sent for Basil and commanded him to embrace the religious sentiments of the emperor, menacing him with death in case of non-compliance.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:10
verses.text: Basil replied that it would be great gain to him and the grant of the highest favor to be delivered as quickly as possible from the bondage of the body.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:11
verses.text: The prefect gave him the rest of the day and the approaching night for deliberation, and advised him not to rush imprudently into obvious danger, but that he should come on the day after and declare his opinion.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:12
verses.text: "I do not require to deliberate," replied Basil.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:13
verses.text: "My determination will be the same to-morrow as it is to-day; for since I am a creature I can never be induced to worship that which is similar to myself and worship it as God; neither will I conform to your religion, nor to that of the emperor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:14
verses.text: Although your distinction may be great, and although you have the honor of ruling no inconsiderable portion of the empire, yet I ought not on these accounts to seek to please men, and, at the same time, belittle that Divine faith which neither loss of goods, nor exile, nor condemnation to death would ever impel me to betray.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:15
verses.text: Inflictions of this nature have never excited in my mind one pang of sorrow.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:16
verses.text: I possess nothing but a cloak and a few books.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:17
verses.text: I dwell on the earth as a traveler.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:18
verses.text: The body through its weakness would have the better of all sensation and torture after the first blow".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:19
verses.text: The prefect admired the courage evinced in this bold reply, and communicated the circumstance to the emperor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:20
verses.text: On the festival of the Epiphany, the emperor repaired to the church, with the rulers and his guards, presented gifts at the holy table, and held a conference with Basil, whose wisdom and whose order and arrangement in the conduct of the priesthood and the church elicited his praise.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:21
verses.text: Not long after, however, the calumny of his enemies prevailed, and Basil was condemned to banishment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:22
verses.text: The night for the execution of the edict was at hand; the son of the emperor suddenly fell ill with a pressing and dangerous fever.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:23
verses.text: The father prostrated himself on the earth and wept over the son who was still alive, and not knowing what other measures to take towards effecting the recovery of his son, he dispatched some of his attendants to Basil to come and visit the prostrate child; because he himself feared to summon the bishop, on account of the injury just inflicted upon him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:24
verses.text: Immediately on the arrival of Basil, the boy began to rally; so that many maintain that his recovery would have been complete, had not some heretics been summoned to pray with Basil for the restoration of the boy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:25
verses.text: It is said that the prefect, likewise, fell ill; but that on his repentance, and on prayer being offered to God, he was restored to health.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 16:26
verses.text: The instances above adduced are quite inadequate to convey an idea of the wonderful endowments of Basil; his extreme addiction to the philosophic life and astonishing powers of eloquence attracted great celebrity.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 17:2
verses.text: —Friendship of Basil and of Gregory, the Theologian; being Peers in Wisdom, they defend the Nicene Doctrines.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 17:3
verses.text: Basil and Gregory were contemporaries, and they were recognized to be equally intent, so to speak, upon the cultivation of the virtues.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 17:4
verses.text: They  had both studied in their youth at Athens, under Himerius and Proaeresius, the most approved sophists of the age; and afterwards at Antioch, under Libanius, the Syrian.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 17:5
verses.text: But as they subsequently conceived a contempt for sophistry and the study of the law, they determined to study philosophy according to the law of the Church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 17:6
verses.text: After having spent some time in the pursuit of the sciences, taught by pagan philosophers, they entered upon the study of the commentaries which Origen and the best approved authors who lived before and after his time, have written in explanation of the Sacred Scriptures.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 17:7
verses.text: They rendered great assistance to those who, like themselves, maintained the Nicene doctrines, for they manfully opposed the dogmas of the Arians, proving that these heretics did not rightly understand either the data upon which they proceeded, nor the opinions of Origen, upon which they mainly depended.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 17:8
verses.text: These two holy men divided the perils of their undertaking, either by mutual agreement, or, as I have been informed, by lot.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 17:9
verses.text: The cities in the neighborhood of Pontus fell to the lot of Basil; and here he founded numerous monasteries, and, by teaching the people, he persuaded them to hold like views with himself.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 17:10
verses.text: After the death of his father, Gregory acted as bishop of the small city of Nazianzus,  but resided on that account in a variety of places, and especially at Constantinople.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 17:11
verses.text: Not long after he was appointed by the vote of many priests to act as president of the people there; for there was then neither bishop nor church in Constantinople, and the doctrines of the council of Nicaea were almost extinct.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:2
verses.text: —The Persecution which occurred at Antioch, on the Orontes.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:3
verses.text: The Place of Prayer in Edessa, called after the Apostle Thomas; the Assembly there, and Confession of the Inhabitants of Edessa.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:4
verses.text: The emperor went to Antioch, and entirely ejected from the churches of that city and of the neighboring cities all those who adhered to the Nicene doctrines;  moreover, he oppressed them with manifold punishments; as some affirm, he commanded many to be put to death in various ways, and caused others to be cast into the river Orontes.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:5
verses.text: Having heard that there was a magnificent oratory at Edessa, named after the Apostle Thomas, he went to see it.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:6
verses.text: He beheld the members of the Catholic Church assembled for worship in the plain before the walls of the city; for there, too, they had been deprived of their houses of prayer.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:7
verses.text: It is said that the emperor reproached the prefect thoroughly and struck him on the jaw with his fist for having permitted these congregations contrary to his edict.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:8
verses.text: Modestus (for this was the name of the prefect), although he was himself a heretic, secretly warned the people of Edessa not to meet for prayer on the accustomed spot the next day; for he had received orders from the emperor to punish all who should be seized.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:9
verses.text: He uttered such threats with the forethought that none, or at least but a few, would incur danger, and with the desire to appease the wrath of the monarch.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:10
verses.text: But the people of Edessa, totally disregarding the threat, ran together with more than their customary zeal, and filled the usual place of meeting.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:11
verses.text: Modestus, on being apprised of their proceedings, was undecided as to what measures ought to be adopted, and repaired in embarrassment to the plain with the throng.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:12
verses.text: A woman, leading a child by the hand, and trailing her mantle in a way unbefitting the decency of women, forced her way through the files of the soldiers who were conducted by the prefect, as if bent upon some affair of importance.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:13
verses.text: Modestus remarked her conduct, ordered her to be arrested, and summoned her into his presence, to inquire the cause of her running.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:14
verses.text: She replied that she was hastening to the plain where the members of the Catholic Church were assembled.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:15
verses.text: "Know you not," replied Modestus, "that the prefect is on his way thither for the purpose of condemning to death all who are found on the spot?" "I have heard so," replied she, "and this is the very reason of my haste; for I am fearful of arriving too late, and thus losing the honor of martyrdom for God".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:16
verses.text: The governor having asked her why she took her child with her, she replied, "In order that he may share in the common suffering, and participate in the same reward".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:17
verses.text: Modestus, struck with astonishment at the courage of this woman, went to the emperor, and, acquainting him with what had occurred, persuaded him not to carry out a design which he showed to be disgraceful and disastrous.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 18:18
verses.text: Thus was the Christian faith confessed by the whole city of Edessa.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 19:2
verses.text: —Death of the Great Athanasius; the Elevation of Lucius, who was Arian-Minded, to the See; the Numerous Calamities he brought upon the Churches in Egypt; Peter, who served after Athanasius, passed over to Rome.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 19:3
verses.text: Athanasius, bishop of the church of Alexandria, died about this period, after having completed his high-priesthood in about forty-six years.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 19:4
verses.text: The Arians having received early intelligence of his death, Euzoïus, president of the Arians at Antioch, and Magnus, the chief treasurer, were sent by the emperor, and lost no time in seizing and imprisoning Peter, whom Athanasius had appointed to succeed him in the bishopric; and they forthwith transferred the government of the church to Lucius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 19:5
verses.text: Hence those in Egypt suffered more grievously than those in other places, and misfortunes piled upon misfortunes oppressed the members of the Catholic Church; for as soon as Lucius settled in Alexandria, he attempted to take possession of the churches; he met with opposition from the people, and the clergy and holy virgins were accused as originators of the sedition.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 19:6
verses.text: Some made their escape as if the city had fallen into the hands of an enemy; others were seized and imprisoned.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 19:7
verses.text: Some of the prisoners were afterwards dragged from the dungeons to be torn with hooks and thongs, while others were burned by means of flaming torches.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 19:8
verses.text: It seemed wonderful how they could possibly survive the tortures to which they were subjected.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 19:9
verses.text: Banishment or even death itself would have been preferable to such sufferings.
