verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 19:10
verses.text: Peter, the bishop, made his escape from prison; and embarking on board a ship, proceeded to Rome, the bishop of which church held the same sentiments as himself.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 19:11
verses.text: Thus the Arians, although not many in number, remained in possession of the churches.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 19:12
verses.text: At the same time, an edict was issued by the emperor, enacting that as many of the followers of the Nicene doctrines should be ejected from Alexandria and the rest of Egypt, as might be directed by Lucius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 19:13
verses.text: Euzoïus, having thus accomplished all his designs, returned to Antioch.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:2
verses.text: —Persecution of the Egyptian Monks, and of the Disciples of St.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:3
verses.text: Antony.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:4
verses.text: They were enclosed in a Certain Island on Account of their Orthodoxy; the Miracles which they Wrought.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:5
verses.text: Lucius went with the general of the soldiers in Egypt, against the monks in the desert;  for he imagined that if he could overcome their opposition by interrupting the tranquillity which they loved, he would meet with fewer obstacles in drawing over to his party the Christians who inhabited the cities.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:6
verses.text: The monasteries of this country were governed by several individuals of eminent sanctity, who were strenuously opposed to the heresy of Arius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:7
verses.text: The people, who were neither willing nor competent to enter upon the investigation of doctrinal questions, received their opinions from them, and thought with them; for they were persuaded that men whose virtue was manifested by their deeds were in possession of truth.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:8
verses.text: We have heard that the leaders of these Egyptian ascetics were two men of the name of Macarius, of whom mention has already been made,  Pambo and Heraclides, and other disciples of Antony.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:9
verses.text: On reflecting that the Arians could never succeed in establishing an ascendency over the Catholic Church, unless the monks could be drawn over to their party, Lucius determined to have recourse to force to compel the monks to side with him, since he was unable to persuade them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:10
verses.text: But here again his scheme failed; for the monks were prepared to subject their necks to the sword rather than to swerve from the Nicene doctrines.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:11
verses.text: It is related that, at the very time that the soldiers were about to attack them, a man whose limbs were withered and who was unable to stand on his feet was carried to them; and that when they had anointed him with oil, and commanded him in the name of Christ, whom Lucius persecuted, to arise and go to his house, he suddenly became whole.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:12
verses.text: This miraculous cure openly manifested the necessity of adopting the sentiments of those to whom God himself had testified as possessing the truth, while Lucius was condemned, in that God heard their prayers and had healed the sick.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:13
verses.text: But the plotters against the monks were not led to repentance by this miracle; on the contrary, they arrested these holy men by night, and conveyed them to an island of Egypt, concealed in the swamps.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:14
verses.text: The inhabitants of this island had never heard of the Christian faith, and were devoted to the service of demons: the island contained a temple of great antiquity which was held in great reverence.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:15
verses.text: It is said that when the monks landed on the island, the daughter of the priest, who was possessed of a devil, went to them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:16
verses.text: The girl ran screaming towards them; and the people of the island, astonished at her sudden and strange conduct, followed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:17
verses.text: When she drew near the ship in which were the holy messengers, she flung herself pleadingly upon the ground, and exclaimed supplicatingly in a loud voice, "Wherefore are you come to us, O servants of the great God? for we have long dwelt in this island as our residence; we have troubled no one.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:18
verses.text: Unknown to men, we have concealed ourselves here, and are everywhere surrounded by these marshes.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:19
verses.text: If, however, it please you, accept our possessions, and fix your abode here; we will quit the island".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:20
verses.text: Such were her utterances.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:21
verses.text: Macarius and his companions rebuked the demon, and the girl became sane.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:22
verses.text: Her father and all her house, with the inhabitants of the island, immediately embraced Christianity, and after demolishing their temple, they transformed it into a church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:23
verses.text: On these occurrences being reported at Alexandria, Lucius was overcome with immoderate grief; and, fearing lest he should incur the hatred of his own partisans, and be accused of warring against God, and not against man, he sent secret orders for Macarius and his companions to be re-conveyed to their own dwellings in the wilderness.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:24
verses.text: Thus did Lucius occasion troubles and commotions in Egypt.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:25
verses.text: About the same period, Didymus the philosopher and several other illustrious men acquired great renown.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:26
verses.text: Struck by their virtue, and by that of the monks, the people followed their doctrines and opposed those of the partisans of Lucius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 20:27
verses.text: The Arians, though not so strong in point of numbers as the other party, grievously persecuted the church of Egypt.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:2
verses.text: —List of the Places in which the Nicene Doctrines were Represented; Faith manifested by the Scythians; Vetranio, the Leader of this Race.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:3
verses.text: Arianism met with similar opposition at the same period in Osröene; but in the Cappadocias, Providence allotted such a divine and most educated pair of men,—Basil, the bishop of Caesarea in that country, and Gregory, bishop of Nazianzen.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:4
verses.text: Syria and the neighboring provinces, and more especially the city of Antioch, were plunged into confusion and disorder; for the Arians were very numerous in these parts, and had possession of the churches.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:5
verses.text: The members of the Catholic Church were not, however, few in number.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:6
verses.text: They were called Eustathians and Paulinists, and were under the guidance of Paulinus and Meletius, as has been before stated.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:7
verses.text: It was through their instrumentality that the church of Antioch was preserved from the encroachments of the Arians, and enabled to resist the zeal of the emperor and of those in power about him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:8
verses.text: Indeed, it appears that in all the churches which were governed by brave men, the people did not deviate from their former opinions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:9
verses.text: It is said that this was the cause of the firmness with which the Scythians adhered to their faith.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:10
verses.text: There are in this country a great number of cities, villages, and fortresses.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:11
verses.text: The metropolis is called Tomi; it is a large and populous city, and lies on the sea-shore to the left of one sailing to the sea, called the Euxine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:12
verses.text: According to an ancient custom which still prevails, all the churches of the whole country are under the sway of one bishop.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:13
verses.text: Vetranio ruled over these churches at the period that the emperor visited Tomi.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:14
verses.text: Valens repaired to the church, and strove, according to his usual custom, to gain over the bishop to the heresy of Arius; but this latter manfully opposed his arguments, and after a courageous defense of the Nicene doctrines, quitted the emperor and proceeded to another church, whither he was followed by the people.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:15
verses.text: Almost the entire city had crowded to see the emperor, for they expected that something extraordinary would result from this interview with the bishop.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:16
verses.text: Valens was extremely offended at being left alone in the church with his attendants, and in resentment, condemned Vetranio to banishment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:17
verses.text: Not long after, however, he recalled him, because, I believe, he apprehended an insurrection; for the Scythians were offended at the absence of their bishop.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:18
verses.text: He well knew that the Scythians were a courageous nation, and that their country, by the position of its places, possessed many natural advantages which rendered it necessary to the Roman Empire, for it served as a barrier to ward off the barbarians.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:19
verses.text: Thus was the intention of the ruler openly frustrated by Vetranio.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:20
verses.text: The Scythians themselves testify that he was good in all other respects and eminent for the virtue of his life.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:21
verses.text: The resentment of the emperor was visited upon all the clergy except those of the Western churches; for Valentinian, who reigned over the Western regions, was an admirer of the Nicene doctrines, and was imbued with so much reverence for religion, that he never imposed any commands upon the priests, nor ever attempted to introduce any alteration for better or for worse in ecclesiastical regulations.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 21:22
verses.text: Although he had become one of the best of emperors, and had shown his capacity to rule affairs, he considered that ecclesiastical matters were beyond the range of his jurisdiction.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 22:2
verses.text: —At that Time, the Doctrine of the Holy Ghost was agitated, and it was decided that he is to be considered Consubstantial with the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 22:3
verses.text: A question was renewed at this juncture which had previously excited much inquiry and now more; namely, whether the Holy Ghost is or is not to be considered consubstantial with the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 22:4
verses.text: Many contentions and debates ensued on this subject, similar to those which had been held concerning the nature of God the Word.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 22:5
verses.text: Those who asserted that the Son is dissimilar from the Father, and those who insisted that He is similar in substance to the Father, came to one common opinion concerning the Holy Ghost; for both parties maintained that the Holy Ghost differs in substance, and that He is but the Minister and the third in point of order, honor, and substance.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 22:6
verses.text: Those, on the contrary, who believed that the Son is consubstantial with the Father, held also the same view about the Spirit.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 22:7
verses.text: This doctrine was nobly maintained in Syria by Apolinarius, bishop of Laodicea; in Egypt by Athanasius,  the bishop; and in Cappadocia and in the churches of Pontus by Basil  and Gregory.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 22:8
verses.text: The bishop of Rome, on learning that this question was agitated with great acrimony, and that it of course was augmented daily by controversies, wrote to the churches of the East and urged them to receive the doctrine upheld by the Western clergy; namely, that the three Persons of the Trinity are of the same substance and of equal dignity.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 22:9
verses.text: The question having been thus decided by the Roman churches, peace was restored, and the inquiry appeared to have an end.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:2
verses.text: —Death of Liberius, Bishop of Rome.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:3
verses.text: He is succeeded by Damasus and Syricius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:4
verses.text: Orthodox Doctrines prevail Everywhere throughout the West, except at Milan, where Auxentius is the High-Priest.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:5
verses.text: Synod held at Rome, by which Auxentius is deposed; the Definition which it sent by Letter.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:6
verses.text: About this period Liberius died,  and Damasus succeeded to the see of Rome.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:7
verses.text: A deacon named Ursicius, who had obtained some votes in his favor, but could not endure the defeat, therefore caused himself to be clandestinely ordained by some bishops of little note, and endeavored to create a division among the people and to hold a separate church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:8
verses.text: He succeeded in effecting this division, and some of the people respected him as bishop, while the rest adhered to Damasus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:9
verses.text: This gave rise to much contention and revolt among the people, which at length proceeded to the evil of wounds and murder.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:10
verses.text: The prefect of Rome was obliged to interfere, and to punish many of the people and of the clergy; and he put an end to the attempt of Ursicius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:11
verses.text: With respect to doctrine, however, no dissension arose either at Rome or in any other of the Western churches.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:12
verses.text: The people unanimously adhered to the form of belief established at Nicaea, and regarded the three persons of the Trinity as equal in dignity and in power.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:13
verses.text: Auxentius and his followers differed from the others in opinion; he was then president of the church in Milan, and, in conjunction with a few partisans, was intent upon the introduction of innovations, and the maintenance of the Arian dogma of the dissimilarity of the Son and of the Holy Ghost, according to the inquiry which had last sprung up, in opposition to the unanimous agreement of the Western priests.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:14
verses.text: The bishops of Gaul and of Venetia having reported that similar attempts to disturb the peace of the Church were being made by others among them, the bishops of several provinces assembled not long after at Rome, and decreed that Auxentius and those who held his sentiments should be aliens from their communion.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:15
verses.text: They confirmed the traditional faith established by the council of Nicaea, and annulled all the decrees that had been issued at Ariminum contrary to that faith, under the plea that these decrees had not received the assent of the bishop of Rome, nor of other bishops who agreed with them, and that many who had been present at the Synod, had disapproved of the enactments there made by them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:16
verses.text: That such was the decision really formed by the Synod is testified by the epistle  addressed by Damasus, the Roman bishop, and the rest of the assembly, to the bishops of Illyria.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:17
verses.text: It is as follows:  —      "Damasus, Valerius,  and the other bishops of the holy assembly convened at Rome to the dearly beloved brethren settled in Illyria, greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:18
verses.text: "We believe that you uphold and teach to the people our holy faith, which is founded on the doctrine of the apostles.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:19
verses.text: This faith differs in no respect from that defined by the Fathers; neither is it allowable for the priests of God, whose right it is to instruct the wise, to have any other thought.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:20
verses.text: We have, however, been informed by some of our brethren of Gaul and of Venice, that certain individuals are bent upon the introduction of heresy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:21
verses.text: "All bishops should diligently guard against this evil, lest some of their flock should be led by inexperience, and others by simplicity, to oppose the proper interpretations.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:22
verses.text: "Those who devise strange doctrines ought not to be followed; but the opinions of our fathers ought to be retained, whatever may be the diversity of judgment around us.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:23
verses.text: "Hence Auxentius, bishop of Milan, has been publicly declared to be condemned pre-eminently in this matter.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:24
verses.text: It is right, therefore, that all the teachers of the Roman world should be of one mind, and not pollute the faith by divers conflicting doctrines.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:25
verses.text: "For when the malice of the heretics first began to mature itself, as the blasphemy of the Arians has even now done,—may it be far from us,—our fathers to the number of three hundred and eighteen elect, after making an investigation in Nicaea, erected the wall against the weapons of the devil, and repelled the deadly poison by this antidote.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:26
verses.text: "This antidote consists in the belief, that the Father and the Son have one Godhead, one virtue, and one substance (χρῆμα).

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:27
verses.text: It is also requisite to believe that the Holy Ghost is of the same hypostasis.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:28
verses.text: We have decreed that those who hold any other doctrines are to be aliens from our communion.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:29
verses.text: "Some have decreed to discolor this saving definition and adorable view; but in the very beginning, some of the persons who made the innovation at the council of Ariminum, or who were compelled to vote for the change, have since, in some measure, made amends by confessing that they were deceived by certain specious arguments, which did not appear to them to be contrary to the principles laid down by our fathers at Nicaea.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:30
verses.text: The number of individuals congregated at the council of Ariminum proves nothing in prejudice of orthodox doctrines; for the council was held without the sanction of the bishops at Rome, whose opinion, before that of all others, ought to have been received, and without the assent either of Vincentius, who during a very long series of years guarded the episcopate without spot, or of many other bishops who agreed with those last mentioned.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:31
verses.text: "Besides, as has been before stated, those very persons who seemed inclined to something illusory, testified their disapprobation of their own proceedings as soon as they made use of a better judgment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:32
verses.text: Therefore your purity must see that this alone is the faith which was established at Nicaea upon the authority of the apostles, and which must ever be retained inviolate, and that all bishops, whether of the East, or of the West, who profess the Catholic religion, ought to consider it an honor to be in communion with us.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:33
verses.text: We believe that it will not be long before those who maintain other sentiments will be excluded from communion, and deprived of the name and dignity of bishop; so that the people who are now oppressed by the yoke of those pernicious and deceitful principles, may have liberty to breathe.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:34
verses.text: For it is not in the power of these bishops to rectify the error of the people, inasmuch as they are themselves held by error.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:35
verses.text: Let, therefore, the opinion of your honor also be in accord with all the priests of God, in which we believe you to be holy and firm.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 23:36
verses.text: That we ought so to believe along with you will be proved by the exchange of letters with your love".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:2
verses.text: —Concerning St.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:3
verses.text: Ambrose and his Elevation to the High Priesthood; how he persuaded the People to practice Piety.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:4
verses.text: The Novatians of Phrygia and the Passover.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:5
verses.text: The clergy of the West having thus anticipated the designs of those who sought to introduce innovations among them,  carefully continued to preserve the inviolability of the faith which had from the beginning been handed down to them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:6
verses.text: With the solitary exception of Auxentius and his partisans, there were no individuals among them who entertained heterodox opinions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:7
verses.text: Auxentius, however, did not live long after this period.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:8
verses.text: At his death a sedition arose among the people concerning the choice of a bishop for the church of Milan, and the city was in danger.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:9
verses.text: Those who had aspired to the bishopric, and been defeated in their expectations, were loud in their menaces, as is usual in such commotions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:10
verses.text: Ambrosius, who was then the governor of the province, being fearful of the movement of the people, went to the church, and exhorted the people to cease from contention, to remember the laws, and to re-establish concord and the prosperity which springs from peace.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:11
verses.text: Before he had ceased speaking, all his auditors at once suppressed the angry feelings by which they had been mutually agitated against each other, and directed the vote of the bishopric upon him, as a fulfillment of his counsel to harmony.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:12
verses.text: They exhorted him to be baptized, for he was still uninitiated, and begged him to receive the priesthood.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:13
verses.text: After he had refused and declined, and unfeignedly fled the business, the people still insisted, and declared that the contention would never be appeased unless he would accede to their wishes; and at length intelligence of these transactions was conveyed to the court.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:14
verses.text: It is said that the Emperor Valentinian prayed, and returned thanks to God that the very man whom he had appointed governor had been chosen to fill a priestly office.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:15
verses.text: When he was informed of the earnest desires of the people and the refusal of Ambrosius, he inferred that events had been so ordered by God for the purpose of restoring peace to the church of Milan, and commanded that Ambrosius should be ordained as quickly as possible.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:16
verses.text: He was initiated and ordained at the same time, and forthwith proceeded to bring the church under his sway to unanimity of opinion concerning the Divine nature; for, while under the guidance of Auxentius, it had long been rent by dissensions on this subject.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:17
verses.text: We shall hereafter have occasion to speak of the conduct of Ambrosius after his ordination, and of the courageous and holy manner in which he discharged the functions of the priesthood.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:18
verses.text: About this period, the Novatians of Phrygia, contrary to their ancient custom, began to celebrate the festival of the Passover on the same day as the Jews.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:19
verses.text: Novatius, the originator of their heresy, refused to receive those who repented of their sins into communion, and it was in this respect alone that he innovated upon the established doctrine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:20
verses.text: But he and those who succeeded him celebrated the feast of the Passover after the vernal equinox, according to the custom of the Roman church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:21
verses.text: Some Novatian bishops, however, assembled about this time at Pazi, a town of Phrygia, near the source of the river Sangarus, and agreeing not to follow, in this point of discipline, the practice of those who differed in doctrine from them, established a new law; they determined upon keeping the feast of unleavened bread, and upon celebrating the Passover on the same days as the Jews.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:22
verses.text: Agelius, the bishop of the Novatians at Constantinople, and the bishops of the Novatians at Nicaea, Nicomedia, and Cotyaeum, a noted city of Phrygia, did not take part in this Synod, although the Novatians consider them to be lords and colophons, so to speak, of the transactions affecting their heresy and their churches.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 24:23
verses.text: How for this reason, these innovators advanced into divergence, and having cut themselves off, formed a separate church, I will speak of at the right time.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:2
verses.text: —Concerning Apolinarius: Father and Son of that Name.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:3
verses.text: Vitalianus, the Presbyter.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:4
verses.text: On being dislodged from One Kind of Heresy, they incline to Others.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:5
verses.text: About this period, Apolinarius openly devised a heresy, to which his name has since been given.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:6
verses.text: He induced many persons to secede from the Church, and formed separate assemblies.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:7
verses.text: Vitalius, a presbyter of Antioch, and one of the priests of Meletius, concurred with him in the confirmation of his peculiar opinion.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:8
verses.text: In other respects, Vitalius was conspicuous in life and conduct, and was zealous in watching over those committed to his pastoral superintendence; hence he was greatly revered by the people.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:9
verses.text: He seceded from communion with Meletius, joined Apolinarius and presided over those at Antioch who had embraced the same opinions; by the sanctity of his life he attracted a great number of followers, who are still called Vitalians by the citizens of Antioch.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:10
verses.text: It is said he was led to secede from the Church from resentment at the contempt that was manifested towards him by Flavian, then one of his fellow-presbyters, but who was afterwards raised to the bishopric of Antioch.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:11
verses.text: Flavian having prevented him from holding his customary interview with the bishop, he fancied himself despised and entered into communion with Apolinarius, and held him as his friend.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:12
verses.text: From that period the members of this sect have formed separate churches in various cities, under their own bishops, and have established laws differing from those of the Catholic Church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:13
verses.text: Besides the customary sacred order, they sang some metrical songs composed by Apolinarius; for, in addition to his other learning he was a poet, and skilled in a great variety of meters, and by their sweetness he induced many to cleave to him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:14
verses.text: Men sang his strains at convivial meetings and at their daily labor, and women sang them while engaged at the loom.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:15
verses.text: But, whether his tender poems were adapted for holidays, festivals, or other occasions, they were all alike to the praise and glory of God.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:16
verses.text: Damasus, bishop of Rome, and Peter, bishop of Alexandria, were the first to learn that the heresy was creeping among the people, and at a council held at Rome  they voted it to be foreign to the Catholic Church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:17
verses.text: It is said that it was as much from narrowness of mind as from any other cause that Apolinarius made an innovation in doctrine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:18
verses.text: For when Athanasius, who administered the church of Alexandria, was on his road back to Egypt from the place whither he had been banished by Constantine, he had to pass through Laodicea, and that while in that city he formed an intimacy with Apolinarius, which terminated in the strictest friendship.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:19
verses.text: As, however, the heterodox considered it disgraceful to hold communion with Athanasius, George, the bishop of the Arians in that city, ejected Apolinarius in a very insulting manner from the church, under the plea that he had received Athanasius contrary to the canons and holy laws.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:20
verses.text: The bishop did not rest here, but reproached him with crimes which he had committed and repented of at a remote period.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:21
verses.text: For when Theodotus, the predecessor of George, regulated the church of Laodicea, Epiphanius, the sophist, recited a hymn which he had composed in honor of Dionysus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:22
verses.text: Apolinarius, who was then a youth and a pupil of Epiphanius, went to hear the recitation, accompanied by his father, whose name also was Apolinarius, and who was a noted grammarian.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:23
verses.text: After the exordium, Epiphanius, according to the custom always observed at the public recitation of hymns, directed the uninitiated and the profane to go out of doors.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:24
verses.text: But neither Apolinarius the younger nor the elder, nor, indeed, any of the Christians who were present, left the audience.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:25
verses.text: When Theodotus, the bishop, heard that they had been present during the recitation, he was exceedingly displeased; he, however, pardoned the laymen who had committed this error, after they had received a moderate reproof.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:26
verses.text: With respect to Apolinarius, father and son, he convicted them both publicly of their sin, and ejected them from the church; for they both belonged to the clergy, the father being a presbyter, and the son a reader of the Holy Scriptures.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:27
verses.text: After some time had elapsed, and when the father and son had evinced by tears and fasting a degree of repentance adequate to their transgression, Theodotus restored them to their offices in the church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:28
verses.text: When George received the same bishopric, he excommunicated Apolinarius, and treated him as alien to the Church on account of his having, as before stated, received Athanasius into communion.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:29
verses.text: It is said that Apolinarius besought him repeatedly to restore him to communion, but that he was inexorable.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:30
verses.text: Apolinarius, overcome with grief, disturbed the Church, and by innovations in doctrines introduced the aforesaid heresy;  and he thought by means of his eloquence to revenge himself on his enemy by proving that George had deposed one who was more deeply acquainted with the Sacred Scriptures than himself.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:31
verses.text: Thus do the private animosities of the clergy from time to time greatly injure the Church, and divide religion into many heresies.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:32
verses.text: And this is a proof; for had George, like Theodotus, received Apolinarius on his repentance into communion, I believe that we should never have heard of the heresy that bears his name.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 25:33
verses.text: Men are prone, when loaded with opprobrium and contempt, to resort to rivalries and innovations; whereas when treated with justice, they become moderate, and remain in the same position.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:2
verses.text: —Eunomius and his Teacher Aëtius, their Affairs and Doctrines.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:3
verses.text: They were the first who broached One Immersion for the Baptism.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:4
verses.text: About this time, Eunomius,  who had held the church in Cyzicus in place of Eleusius, and who presided over the Arian heresy, devised another heresy besides this, which some have called by his name, but which is sometimes denominated the Anomian heresy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:5
verses.text: Some assert that Eunomius was the first who ventured to maintain that divine baptism ought to be performed by one immersion, and to corrupt, in this manner, the apostolical tradition which has been carefully handed down to the present day.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:6
verses.text: He invented, it is said, a mode of discipline contrary to that of the Church, and disguised the innovation under gravity and greater severity.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:7
verses.text: He was an artist in words and contentions, and delighted in arguments.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:8
verses.text: The generality of those who entertain his sentiments have the same predilections.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:9
verses.text: They do not applaud a good course of life or manner, or mercy towards the needy, unless exhibited by persons of their own sect, so much as skill in disputation and the power of triumphing in debates.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:10
verses.text: Persons possessed of these accomplishments are accounted pious above all others among them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:11
verses.text: Others assert, I believe more truthfully, that Theophronius, a native of Cappadocia, and Eutychius, both zealous propagators of this heresy, seceded from communion with Eunomius during the succeeding reign, and innovated about the other doctrines of Eunomius and about the divine baptism.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:12
verses.text: They asserted that baptism ought not to be administered in the name of the Trinity, but in the name of the death of Christ.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:13
verses.text: It appears that Eunomius broached no new opinion on the subject, but was from the beginning firmly attached to the sentiments of Arius, and remained so.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:14
verses.text: After his elevation to the bishopric of Cyzicus, he was accused by his own clergy of introducing innovations in doctrine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:15
verses.text: Eudoxius, ruler of the Arian heresy at Constantinople, summoned him and obliged him to give an account of his doctrines to the people; finding, however, no fault in him, Eudoxius exhorted him to return to Cyzicus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:16
verses.text: Eunomius, however, replied, that he could not remain with people who regarded him with suspicion; and, it is said, seized the opportunity for secession, although it seems that, in taking this step he was really actuated by the resentment he felt at the refusal which Aëtius, his teacher, had met with, of being received into communion.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:17
verses.text: Eunomius, it is added, dwelt with Aëtius, and never deviated from his original sentiments.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:18
verses.text: Such are the conflicting accounts of various individuals; some narrate the circumstances in one way, and some in another.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:19
verses.text: But whether it was Eunomius, or any other person, who first made these innovations upon the tradition of baptism, it seems to me that such innovators, whoever they may have been, were alone in danger, according to their own representation, of quitting this life without having received the divine baptism; for if, after they had been baptized according to the mode recommended from the beginning, they found it impossible to rebaptize themselves, it must be admitted that they introduced a practice to which they had not themselves submitted, and thus undertook to administer to others what had never been administered to them by themselves nor by others.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:20
verses.text: Thus, after having laid down the dogma by some non-existent principle and private assumption, they proceeded to bestow upon others what they had not themselves received.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:21
verses.text: The absurdity of this assumption is manifest from their own confession; for they admit that the uninitiated have not the power to baptize others.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:22
verses.text: Now, according to their opinion, he who has not been baptized in conformity with their tradition is unbaptized as one not properly initiated, and they confirm this opinion by their practice, inasmuch as they rebaptize all those who join their sect, although previously initiated according to the tradition of the Catholic Church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:23
verses.text: These varying dogmas are the sources of innumerable troubles to religion; and many are deterred from embracing Christianity by the diversity of opinion which prevails in matters of doctrine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:24
verses.text: The disputes daily became stronger, and, as in the beginning of heresies, they grew; for they had leaders who were not deficient in zeal or power of words; indeed, it appears that the greater part of the Catholic Church would have been subverted by this heresy, had it not found opponents in Basil and Gregory, the Cappadocians.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:25
verses.text: The reign of Theodosius began a little while after; he banished the founders of heretical sects from the populous parts of the empire to the more desert regions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:26
verses.text: But, lest those who read my history should be ignorant of the precise nature of the two heresies to which I have more especially alluded, I think it necessary to state that Aëtius, the Syrian, was the originator of the heresy usually attributed to Eunomius; and that, like Arius, he maintained that the Son is dissimilar from the Father, that He is a created being, and was created out of what had no previous existence.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:27
verses.text: Those who held these views were formerly called Aëtians; but afterwards, during the reign of Constantius, when, as we have stated, some parties maintained that the Son is consubstantial with the Father, and others that He is like in substance to the Father, and when the council of Ariminum had decreed that the Son is only to be considered like unto the Father, Aëtius was condemned to banishment, as guilty of impiety and blasphemy against God.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:28
verses.text: For some time subsequently his heresy seemed to have been suppressed; for neither any other man of note, nor even Eunomius, ventured openly upon undertaking its defense.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:29
verses.text: But when Eunomius was raised to the church of Cyzicus in place of Eleusius, he could no longer quietly restrain himself, and in open debate he brought forward again the tenets of Aëtius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 26:30
verses.text: Hence, as it often happens that the names of the original founders of heretical sects pass into oblivion, the followers of Eunomius were designated by his own name, although he merely renewed the heresy of Aëtius, and promulgated it with greater boldness than was done by him who first handed it down.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:2
verses.text: —Account Given, by Gregory the Theologian, of Apolinarius and Eunomius, in a Letter to Nectarius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:3
verses.text: Their Heresy was distinguished by the Philosophy of the Monks who were then Living, for the Heresy of these two held Nearly the Entire East.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:4
verses.text: It is obvious that Eunomius and Aëtius held the same opinions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:5
verses.text: In several passages of his writings, Eunomius boasts and frequently testifies that Aëtius was his instructor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:6
verses.text: Gregory, bishop of Nazianzen, speaks in the following terms of Apolinarius in a letter addressed to Nectarius, the leader of the church in Constantinople:  "Eunomius, who is a constant source of trouble among us, is not content with being a burden to us himself, but would consider himself to blame if he did not strive to drag every one with him to the destruction whither he is hastening.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:7
verses.text: Such conduct, however, may be tolerated in some degree.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:8
verses.text: The most grievous calamity against which the Church has now to struggle arises from the audacity of the Apolinarians.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:9
verses.text: I know not how your Holiness could have agreed that they should be as free to hold meetings as we ourselves.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:10
verses.text: You have been fully instructed by the grace of God, in the Divine mysteries, and not only understand the defense of the Word of God, but also whatever innovations have been made by heretics against the sound faith; yet it may not be amiss for your revered Excellency to hear from our narrowness, that a book written by Apolinarius has fallen into my hands, in which the proposition surpasses all forms of heretical pravity.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:11
verses.text: He affirms that the flesh assumed for the transformation of our nature, under the dispensation of the only begotten Son of God was not acquired for this end; but that this carnal nature existed in the Son from the beginning.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:12
verses.text: He substantiates this evil hypothesis by a misapplication of the following words of Scripture: 'No man hath ascended up into heaven.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:13
verses.text: '  He alleges from this text, that Christ was the Son of man before He descended from heaven, and that when He did descend, He brought with Him His own flesh which He had already possessed in heaven which was before the ages and essentially united.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:14
verses.text: He also states another apostolic saying: 'The second man is from heaven.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:15
verses.text: '  He, moreover, maintains that the man who came down from heaven was destitute of intellect (νοῦς), but that the Deity of the only begotten Son fulfilled the nature of intellect, and constituted the third part of the human compound.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:16
verses.text: The body and soul (ψυχὴ) formed two parts, as in other men, but there was no intellect, but the Word of God filled the place of intellect.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:17
verses.text: Nor does this end the awful spectacle; for the most grievous point of the heresy is, that he asserts that the only-begotten God, the Judge of all men, the Giver of life, and the Destroyer of death, is Himself subject to death; that He suffered in His own Godhead, and that in the resurrection of the body in the third day, the Godhead also was raised from the dead with the body; and that it was raised again from the dead by the Father.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:18
verses.text: It would take too long to recount all the other extravagant doctrines propounded by these heretics".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:19
verses.text: What I have said may, I think, suffice to show the nature of the sentiments maintained by Apolinarius and Eunomius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:20
verses.text: If any one desire more detailed information, I can only refer him to the works on the subject written either by them or by others concerning these men.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:21
verses.text: I do not profess easily to understand or to expound these matters, as it seems to me the fact that these dogmas did not prevail and make further advance is to be attributed, in addition to the causes mentioned, especially to the monks of that period; for all those philosophers in Syria, Cappadocia, and the neighboring provinces, were sincerely attached to the Nicene faith.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:22
verses.text: The eastern regions, however, from Cilicia to Phoenicia, were endangered by the heresy of Apolinarius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:23
verses.text: The heresy of Eunomius was spread from Cilicia and the mountains of Taurus as far as the Hellespont and Constantinople.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:24
verses.text: These two heretics found it easy to attract to their respective parties the persons among whom they dwelt, and those of the neighborhood.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:25
verses.text: But the same fate awaited them that had been experienced by the Arians; for the people admired the monks who manifested their virtue by works and believed that they held right opinions, while they turned away from those who held other opinions, as impious and as holding spurious doctrines.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 27:26
verses.text: In the same way the Egyptians were led by the monks to oppose the Arians.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:2
verses.text: —Of the Holy Men who flourished at this Period in Egypt.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:3
verses.text: John, or Amon,  Benus, Theonas, Copres, Helles, Elias, Apelles, Isidore, Serapion, Dioscorus, and Eulogius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:4
verses.text: As this period was distinguished by many holy men,  who devoted themselves to a life of philosophy, it seems requisite to give some account of them, for in that time there flourished a very great abundance of men beloved of God.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:5
verses.text: There was not, it appears, a more celebrated man in Egypt than John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:6
verses.text: He had received from God the power of discerning the future and the most hidden things as clearly as the ancient prophets, and he had, moreover, the gift of healing those who suffered with incurable afflictions and diseases.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:7
verses.text: Or was another eminent man of this period; he had lived in solitude from his earliest youth, occupying himself continually in singing the praises of God.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:8
verses.text: He subsisted on herbs and roots, and his drink was water, when he could find it.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:9
verses.text: In his old age he went, by the command of God, to Thebaïs, where he presided over several monasteries, nor was he without part in divine works.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:10
verses.text: By means of prayer alone he expelled diseases and devils.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:11
verses.text: He knew nothing of letters, nor did he need books to support his memory; for whatever he received into his mind was never afterwards forgotten.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:12
verses.text: Ammon, the leader of the monks called Tabennesiotians, dwelt in the same region, and was followed by about three thousand disciples.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:13
verses.text: Benus and Theonas likewise presided over monastic orders, and possessed the gift of foreknowledge and of prophecy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:14
verses.text: It is said that though Theonas was versed in all the learning of the Egyptians, the Greeks, and the Romans, he practiced silence for the space of thirty years.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:15
verses.text: Benus was never seen to manifest any signs of anger, and never heard to swear, or to utter a false, a vain, a rash, or a useless word.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:16
verses.text: Copres, Helles, and Elias also flourished at this period.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:17
verses.text: It is said that Copres had received from God the power of healing sickness and divers diseases, and of overcoming demons.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:18
verses.text: Helles had from his youth upwards been trained in the monastic life, and he wrought many wonderful works.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:19
verses.text: He could carry fire in his bosom without burning his clothes.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:20
verses.text: He excited his fellow-monks to the practice of virtue by representing that with a good conduct, the display of miracles would follow.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:21
verses.text: Elias, who practiced philosophy near the city of Antinoüs, was at this period about a hundred and ten years of age; before this he said he had passed seventy years alone in the desert.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:22
verses.text: Notwithstanding his advanced age, he was unremitting in the practice of fasting and courageous discipline.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:23
verses.text: Apelles flourished at the same period, and performed numerous miracles in the Egyptian monasteries, near the city of Acoris.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:24
verses.text: He at one time worked as a smith, for this was his trade; and one night the devil undertook to tempt him to incontinence, by appearing before him in the form of a beautiful woman; Apelles, however, seized the iron which was heating in the furnace, and burnt the face of the devil, who screamed like a wild bird and ran away.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:25
verses.text: Isidore, Serapion, and Dioscorus, at this period, were among the most celebrated fathers of the monks.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:26
verses.text: Isidore caused his monastery to be closed, so that no one could obtain egress or ingress, and supplied the wants of those within the walls.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:27
verses.text: Serapion lived in the neighborhood of Arsenoites, and had about a thousand monks under his guidance.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:28
verses.text: He taught all to earn their provisions by their labors and to provide for others who were poor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:29
verses.text: During harvest-time they busied themselves in reaping for pay; they set aside sufficient corn for their own use, and shared it with the rest of the monks.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:30
verses.text: Dioscorus had not more than a hundred disciples; he was a presbyter, and applied himself with great exactness to the duties of his priesthood; he examined and carefully questioned those who presented themselves as candidates for participation in the holy mysteries, so that they might purify their minds and not be without a consciousness of any evil they might have committed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:31
verses.text: The presbyter Eulogius was still more scrupulous in the dispensation of the Divine mysteries.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:32
verses.text: It is said that, when he was officiating in the priestly office, he could discern what was in the minds of those who came to him, so that he could clearly detect sin, and the secret thoughts of each one of his audience.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 28:33
verses.text: He excluded from the altar all who had perpetrated crime or formed evil resolutions, and publicly convicted them of sin; but, on their purifying themselves by repentance, he again received them into communion.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIX.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:2
verses.text: —Concerning the Monks of Thebaïs: Apollos, Dorotheus; concerning Piammon, John, Mark, Macarius, Apollodorus, Moses, Paul, who was in Ferma, Pacho, Stephen, and Pior.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:3
verses.text: Apollos flourished about the same period in Thebaïs.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:4
verses.text: He early devoted himself to a life of philosophy; and after having passed forty years in the desert, he shut himself up, by the command of God, in a cave formed at the foot of a mountain, near a very populous district.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:5
verses.text: By the multitude of his miracles, he soon became distinguished, and was the head of many monks; for he directed them profitably by his instructions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:6
verses.text: Timothy, who conducted the church of Alexandria, has given us a history of his method of discipline and of what divine and marvelous deeds he was a worker; he also narrates the lives of other approved monks, many of whom I have mentioned.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:7
verses.text: In that time many good monks, to the number of about two thousand, preached philosophy in the neighborhood of Alexandria; some in a district called the Hermitage, and others more towards Mareotis and Libya.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:8
verses.text: Dorotheus, a native of Thebes, was among the most celebrated of these monks.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:9
verses.text: He spent the day in collecting stones upon the seashore, which he used in erecting cells to be given to those who were unable to build them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:10
verses.text: During the night, he employed himself in weaving baskets of palm leaves; and these he sold, to obtain the means of subsistence.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:11
verses.text: He ate six ounces of bread with a few vegetables daily, and drank nothing but water.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:12
verses.text: Having accustomed himself to this extreme abstinence from his youth, he continued to observe it in old age.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:13
verses.text: He was never seen to recline on a mat or a bed, nor even to place his limbs in an easy attitude, or willingly to surrender himself to sleep.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:14
verses.text: Sometimes, from natural lassitude, his eyes would involuntarily close when he was at his daily labor or his meals; and when nodding during his eating, the food would fall from his mouth.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:15
verses.text: One day, being utterly overcome by drowsiness, he fell down on the mat; he was displeased at finding himself in this position, and said, in an undertone of voice, "If angels are persuaded to sleep, you will persuade also the zealous".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:16
verses.text: Perhaps he might have said this to himself, or perhaps to the demon who had become an impediment to his zealous exercises.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:17
verses.text: He was once asked by a person who came to him while he was exhausting himself, why he destroyed his body.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:18
verses.text: "Because it destroys me," was his reply.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:19
verses.text: Piammon and John presided over two celebrated Egyptian monasteries near Diolcus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:20
verses.text: They were presbyters who discharged their priesthood very carefully and reverently.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:21
verses.text: It is said that one day, when Piammon was officiating as priest, he beheld an angel standing near the holy table and writing down in a book the names of the monks who were present, while he erased the names of those who were absent.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:22
verses.text: John had received from God such power over sufferings and diseases, that he healed the gouty and restored the paralytic.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:23
verses.text: A very old man, named Benjamin, was practicing philosophy very brilliantly about this period, in the desert near Scetis.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:24
verses.text: God had bestowed upon him the power of relieving the sick of every disease without medicine, by the touch only of his hand, or by means of a little oil consecrated by prayer.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:25
verses.text: The story is, that he was attacked by a dropsy, and his body was swollen to such a size that it became necessary, in order to carry him from his cell, to enlarge the door.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:26
verses.text: As his malady would not admit of his lying in a recumbent posture, he remained, during eight months, seated on a very large skin, and continued to heal the sick, without regretting that his own recovery was not effected.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:27
verses.text: He comforted those who came to visit him, and requested them to pray for his soul; adding that he cared little for his body, for it had been of no service to him when in health, and could not, now that it was diseased, be of any injury to him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:28
verses.text: About the same time the celebrated Mark, Marcarius the younger, Apollonius, and Moses, an Egyptian, dwelt at Scetis.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:29
verses.text: It is said that Mark was, from his youth upwards, distinguished by extreme mildness and prudence; he committed the Sacred Scriptures to memory, and manifested such eminent piety that Macarius himself, the presbyter of Celliae,  declared that he had never given to him what priests present to the initiated at the holy table, but that an angel administered it to him whose hand up to the forearm he declares himself to have seen.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:30
verses.text: Macarius had received from God the power of dispelling demons.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:31
verses.text: A murder which he had unintentionally committed was the original cause of his embracing a life of philosophy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:32
verses.text: He was a shepherd, and led his flock to graze on the banks of Lake Mareotis, when in sport he slew one of his companions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:33
verses.text: Fearful of being delivered up to justice, he fled to the desert.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:34
verses.text: Here he concealed himself during three years, and afterwards erected a small dwelling on the spot, in which he dwelt twenty-five years.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:35
verses.text: He was accustomed to say that he owed much to the calamity that had befallen him in early life, and even called the unintentional murder he had committed a salutary deed, inasmuch as it had been the cause of his embracing philosophy and a blessed mode of life.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:36
verses.text: Apollonius, after passing his life in the pursuits of commerce, retired in his old age to Scetis.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:37
verses.text: On reflecting that he was too old to learn writing or any other art, he purchased with his own money a supply of every kind of drug, and of food suited for the sick, some of which he carried until the ninth hour to the door of every monastery, for the relief of those who were suffering from disease.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:38
verses.text: Finding this practice advantageous to himself, he adopted this mode of life; and when he felt death approaching he delivered his drugs to one whom he exhorted to go and do as he had done.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:39
verses.text: Moses was originally a slave, but was driven from his master's house on account of his immorality.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:40
verses.text: He joined some robbers, and became leader of the band.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:41
verses.text: After having perpetrated many evil deeds and dared some murders, by some sudden conversion he embraced the monastic life, and attained the highest point of philosophy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:42
verses.text: As the healthful and vigorous habit of body which had been induced by his former avocations acted as a stimulus to his imagination and excited a desire for pleasure, he resorted to every possible means of macerating his body; thus, he subsisted on a little bread without cooked food, subjected himself to severe labor, and prayed fifty times daily; he prayed standing, without bending his knees or closing his eyes in sleep.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:43
verses.text: He sometimes went during the night to the cells of the monks and secretly filled their pitchers with water, and this was very laborious, for he had sometimes to go ten, sometimes twenty, and sometimes thirty and more, stadia in quest of water.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:44
verses.text: Notwithstanding all his efforts to macerate his body, it was long before he could subdue his natural vigor of constitution.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:45
verses.text: It is reported that robbers once broke into the dwelling where he was practicing philosophy; he seized and bound them, threw the four men across his shoulders, and bore them to the church, that the monks who were there assembled might deal with them as they thought fit, for he did not consider himself authorized to punish any one.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:46
verses.text: For they say so sudden a conversion from vice to virtue was never before witnessed, nor such rapid attainments in monastical philosophy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:47
verses.text: Hence God rendered him an object of dread to the demons, and he was ordained presbyter over the monks at Scetis.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:48
verses.text: After a life spent in this manner, he died at the age of seventy-five, leaving behind him numerous eminent disciples.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:49
verses.text: Paul, Pachon, Stephen, and Moses, of whom the two latter were Libyans, and Pior, who was an Egyptian, flourished during this reign.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:50
verses.text: Paul dwelt at Ferme, a mountain of Scetis, and presided over five hundred ascetics.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:51
verses.text: He did not labor with his hands, neither did he receive alms of any one, except such food as was necessary for his subsistence.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:52
verses.text: He did nothing but pray, and daily offered up to God three hundred prayers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:53
verses.text: He placed three hundred pebbles in his bosom, for fear of omitting any of these prayers; and, at the conclusion of each, he took away one of the pebbles.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:54
verses.text: When there were no pebbles remaining, he knew that he had gone through the whole course of his prescribed prayers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:55
verses.text: Pachon also flourished during this period at Scetis.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:56
verses.text: He followed this career from youth to extreme old age, without ever being found unmanly in self-control by the appetites of the body, the passions of the soul, or a demon,—in short, in all those things which the philosopher should conquer.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:57
verses.text: Stephen dwelt at Mareotis near Marmarica.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:58
verses.text: During sixty years, through exactness, he attained the perfection of asceticism, became very noted as a monk, and was intimate with Antony the Great.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:59
verses.text: He was very mild and prudent, and his usual style of conversation was sweet and profitable, and well calculated to comfort the souls of the afflicted, to transform them into good spirits, if even they had previously been depressed by griefs which seemed necessary.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:60
verses.text: He behaved similarly about his own afflictions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:61
verses.text: He was troubled with a severe and incurable ulcer, and surgeons were employed to operate upon the diseased members.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:62
verses.text: During the operation Stephen employed himself in weaving palm leaves, and exhorted those who were around him not to concern themselves about his sufferings.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:63
verses.text: He told them to have no other thought than that God does nothing but for our good, and that his affliction would tend to his real welfare, inasmuch as it would perhaps atone for his sins, it being better to be judged in this life than in the life to come.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:64
verses.text: Moses was celebrated for his meekness, his love, and his power of healing of sufferings by prayer.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:65
verses.text: Pior determined, from his youth, to devote himself to a life of philosophy; and, with this view, quitted his father's house after having made a vow that he would never again look upon any of his relations.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:66
verses.text: After fifty years had expired, one of his sisters heard that he was still alive, and she was so transported with joy at this unexpected intelligence, that she could not rest till she had seen him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:67
verses.text: The bishop of the place where she resided was so affected by the groans and tears of the aged woman, that he wrote to the leaders of the monks in the desert of Scetis, desiring them to send Pior to him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:68
verses.text: The superiors accordingly directed him to repair to the city of his birth, and he could not say nay, for disobedience was regarded as unlawful by the monks of Egypt, and I think also by other monks.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:69
verses.text: He went with another monk to the door of his father's house, and caused himself to be announced.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:70
verses.text: When he heard the door being opened, he closed his eyes, and calling his sister by name, he said to her, "I am Pior, your brother; look at me as much as you please".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:71
verses.text: His sister was delighted beyond measure at again beholding him, and returned thanks to God.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:72
verses.text: He prayed at the door where he stood, and then returned to the place where he lived; there he dug a well, and found that the water was bitter, but he persevered in the use of it till his death.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:73
verses.text: Then the height to which he had carried his self-denial was known; for after he died, several attempted to practice philosophy in the place where he had dwelt, but found it impossible to remain there.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:74
verses.text: I am convinced that, had it not been for the principles of philosophy which he had espoused, he could easily have changed the water to a sweet taste by prayer; for he caused water to flow in a spot where none had existed previously.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:75
verses.text: It is said that some monks, under the guidance of Moses, undertook to dig a well, but the expected vein did not appear, nor did any depth yield the water, and they were about to abandon the task, when, about midday, Pior joined them; he first embraced them, and then rebuked their want of faith and littleness of soul; he then descended into the pit they had excavated; and, after engaging in prayer, struck the ground thrice with a rod.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:76
verses.text: A spring of water soon after rose to the surface, and filled the whole excavation.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 29:77
verses.text: After prayer, Pior departed; and though the monks urged him to break his fast with them, he refused, alleging that he had not been sent to them for that purpose, but merely in order to perform the act he had effected.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:1
verses.text: Chapter XXX.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:2
verses.text: —Monks of Scetis: Origen, Didymus, Cronion, Orsisius, Putubatus, Arsion, Serapion, Ammon, Eusebius, and Dioscorus, the Brethren who are called Long, and Evagrius the Philosopher.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:3
verses.text: At this period, Origen, one of the disciples of Antony the Great, was still living at a great age, in the monasteries of Scetis.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:4
verses.text: Also, Didymus, and Cronion, who was about one hundred and ten years of age, Arsisius the Great, Putubatus, Arsion, and Serapion, all of whom had been contemporary with Antony the Great.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:5
verses.text: They had grown old in the exercise of philosophy, and were at this period presiding over the monasteries.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:6
verses.text: There were some holy men among them who were young and middle aged, but who were celebrated for their excellent and good qualities.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:7
verses.text: Among these were Ammonius, Eusebius, and Dioscorus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:8
verses.text: They were brothers, but on account of their height of stature were called the "Long Brothers".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:9
verses.text: It is said that Ammon attained the summit of philosophy, and consequently overcame the love of ease and pleasure.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:10
verses.text: He was very studious, and had read the works of Origen, of Didymus, and of other ecclesiastical writers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:11
verses.text: From his youth to the day of his death he never tasted anything, with the exception of bread, that had been prepared by means of fire.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:12
verses.text: He was once chosen to be ordained bishop; and after urging every argument that could be devised in rejection of the honor, but in vain, he cut off one of his ears, and said to those who had come for him, "Go away.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:13
verses.text: Henceforward the priestly law forbids my ordination, for the person of a priest should be perfect".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:14
verses.text: Those who had been sent for him accordingly departed; but, on ascertaining that the Church does not observe the Jewish law in requiring a priest to be perfect in all his members, but merely requires him to be irreprehensible in point of morals, they returned to Ammon, and endeavored to take him by force.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:15
verses.text: He protested to them that, if they attempted any violence against him, he would cut out his tongue; and, terrified at this menace, they immediately took their departure.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:16
verses.text: Ammon was ever after surnamed Parotes.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:17
verses.text: Some time afterwards, during the ensuing reign, the wise Evagrius formed an intimacy with him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:18
verses.text: Evagrius  was a wise man, powerful in thought and in word, and skillful in discerning the arguments which led to virtue and to vice, and capable in urging others to imitate the one, and to eschew the other.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:19
verses.text: His eloquence is fully attested by the works he has left behind him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:20
verses.text: With respect to his moral character, it is said that he was totally free from all pride or superciliousness, so that he was not elated when just commendations were awarded him, nor displeased when unjust reproaches were brought against him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:21
verses.text: He was a citizen of Iberia, near the Euxine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:22
verses.text: He had philosophized and studied the Sacred Scriptures under Gregory, bishop of Nazianzen, and had filled the office of archdeacon when Gregory administered the church in Constantinople.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:23
verses.text: He was handsome in person, and careful in his mode of attire; and hence an acquaintanceship he had formed with a certain lady excited the jealousy of her husband, who plotted his death.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:24
verses.text: While the plot was about being carried forward into deed, God sent him while sleeping, a fearful and saving vision in a dream.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:25
verses.text: It appeared to him that he had been arrested in the act of committing some crime, and that he was bound hand and foot in irons.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:26
verses.text: As he was being led before the magistrates to receive the sentence of condemnation, a man who held in his hand the book of the Holy Gospels addressed him, and promised to deliver him from his bonds, and confirmed this with an oath, provided he would quit the city.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:27
verses.text: Evagrius touched the book, and made oath that he would do so.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:28
verses.text: Immediately his chains appeared to fall off, and he awoke.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:29
verses.text: He was convinced by this divine dream, and fled the danger.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:30
verses.text: He resolved upon devoting himself to a life of asceticism, and proceeded from Constantinople to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 30:31
verses.text: Some time after he went to visit the philosophers of Scetis, and gladly determined to live there.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXI.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:2
verses.text: —Concerning the Monks of Nitria, and the Monasteries called Cells; about the One in Rhinocorura; about Melas, Dionysius, and Solon.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:3
verses.text: They call this place Nitria.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:4
verses.text: It is inhabited by a great number of persons devoted to a life of philosophy, and derives its name from its vicinity to a village in which nitre is gathered.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:5
verses.text: It contains about fifty monasteries, built tolerably near to each other, some of which are inhabited by monks who live together in society, and others by monks who have adopted a solitary mode of existence.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:6
verses.text: More in the interior of the desert, about seventy stadia from this locality, is another place called Cellia,  throughout which numerous little dwellings are dispersed hither and thither, and hence its name; but at such a distance that those who dwell in them can neither see nor hear each other.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:7
verses.text: They assemble together on the first and last days of each week; and if any monk happen to be absent, it is evident that he has been left behind involuntarily, having been hindered by suffering some disease; they do not all go immediately to see and nurse him, but each one in turn at different times, and bearing whatever each has suitable for disease.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:8
verses.text: Except for such a cause, they seldom converse together, unless, indeed, there be one among them capable of communicating further knowledge concerning God and the salvation of the soul.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:9
verses.text: Those who dwell in the cells are those who have attained the summit of philosophy, and who are therefore able to regulate their own conduct, to live alone, and are separated from the others for the sake of quietude.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:10
verses.text: This is what I had briefly to state concerning Scetis and its philosophers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:11
verses.text: Some one would probably censure my writing as prolix, were I to enter into further details concerning their mode of life; for they have established individual courses of life, labors, customs, exercises, abstinence, and time, divided naturally according to the age of the individual.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:12
verses.text: Rhinocorura was also celebrated at this period, on account of the holy men, not from abroad, but who were natives of the place.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:13
verses.text: I have heard  that the most eminent philosophers among them were Melas, who then administered the church of the country; Dionysius, who presided over a monastery situated to the north of the city; and Solon, the brother and successor to the bishopric of Melas.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:14
verses.text: It is said that when the decree for the ejection of all priests opposed to Arianism was issued, the officers appointed to apprehend Melas found him engaged as the lowest servant, in trimming the lights of the church, with a girdle soiled with oil on his cloak, and carrying the wicks.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:15
verses.text: When they asked him for the bishop, he replied that he was within, and that he would conduct them to him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:16
verses.text: As they were fatigued with their journey, he led them to the episcopal dwelling, made them sit down at table, and gave them to eat of such things as he had.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:17
verses.text: After the repast, he supplied them with water to wash their hands; for he served the guests, and then told them who he was.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:18
verses.text: Amazed at his conduct, they confessed the mission on which they had arrived; but from respect to him, gave him full liberty to go whereever he would.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:19
verses.text: He, however, replied that he would not shrink from the sufferings to which the other bishops who maintained the same sentiments as himself were exposed, and that he was willing to go into exile.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:20
verses.text: Having philosophized from his youth, he had exercised himself in all the monastic virtues.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:21
verses.text: Solon quitted the pursuits of commerce to embrace a monastic life, a measure which tended greatly to his welfare; for under the instruction of his brother and other ascetics, he progressed rapidly in piety towards God, and in goodness towards his neighbor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:22
verses.text: The church of Rhinocorura having been thus, from the beginning, under the guidance of such exemplary bishops, never afterwards swerved from their precepts, and produced good men.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 31:23
verses.text: The clergy of this church dwell in one house, sit at the same table, and have everything in common.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:2
