verses.text: —Monks of Palestine: Hesycas, Epiphanius, who was afterwards in Cyprus, Ammonius, and Silvanus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:3
verses.text: Many monastical institutions flourished in Palestine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:4
verses.text: Many of those whom I enumerated under the reign of Constantius were still cultivating the science.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:5
verses.text: They and their associates attained the summit of philosophical perfection, and added still greater reputation to their monasteries; and among them Hesycas,  a companion of Hilarion, and Epiphanius, afterwards bishop of Salamis in Cyprus, deserve to be particularly noticed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:6
verses.text: Hesycas devoted himself to a life of philosophy in the same locality where his master had formerly resided; and Epiphanius  fixed his abode near the village of Besauduc, which was his birthplace, in the government of Eleutheropolis.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:7
verses.text: Having been instructed from his youth by the most celebrated ascetics, and having on this account passed the most of his time in Egypt, Epiphanius became most celebrated in Egypt and Palestine by his attainments in monastic philosophy, and was chosen by the inhabitants of Cyprus to act as bishop of the metropolis of their island.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:8
verses.text: Hence he is, I think, the most revered man under the whole heaven, so to speak; for he fulfilled his priesthood in the concourse of a large city and in a seaport; and when he threw himself into civil affairs, he conducted them with so much virtue that he became known in a little while to all citizens and every variety of foreigner; to some, because they had seen the man himself, and had experience of his manner of living; and to others, who had learned it from these spectators.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:9
verses.text: Before he went to Cyprus, he resided for some time, during the present reign, in Palestine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:10
verses.text: At the same period in the monasteries, Salamines, Phuscon, Malachion, and Crispion, four brethren, were highly distinguished: they practiced philosophy near Bethelia, a village of Gaza; they were of a resident noble family, and had been instructed in philosophy by Hilarion.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:11
verses.text: It is related that the brothers were once journeying homewards, when Malachion was suddenly snatched away and became invisible; soon afterwards, however, he reappeared and continued the journey with his brothers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:12
verses.text: He did not long survive this occurrence, but died in the flower of his youth.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:13
verses.text: He was not behind men of advanced age in the philosophy of virtuous life and of piety.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:14
verses.text: Ammonius lived at a distance of ten stadia from those last mentioned; he dwelt near Capharcobra, the place of his birth, a town of Gaza.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:15
verses.text: He was very exact and courageous in carrying through asceticism.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:16
verses.text: I think that Silvanus, a native of Palestine, to whom, on account of his high virtue, an angel was once seen to minister, practiced philosophy about the same time in Egypt.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 32:17
verses.text: Then he lived at Mount Sinai, and afterwards founded at Gerari, in the wady, a very extensive and most noted coenobium for many good men, over which the excellent Zacharias subsequently presided.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 33:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 33:2
verses.text: —Monks of Syria and Persia: Battheus, Eusebius, Barges, Halas, Abbo, Lazarus, Abdaleus, Zeno, Heliodorus, Eusebius of Carrae, Protogenes, and Aones.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 33:3
verses.text: Let us pass thence to Syria and Persia,  the parts adjacent to Syria.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 33:4
verses.text: We shall find that the monks of these countries emulated those of Egypt in the practice of philosophy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 33:5
verses.text: Battheus, Eusebius, Barges, Halas, Abbos, Lazarus, who attained the episcopal dignity, Abdaleus, Zeno, and Heliodorus, flourished in Nisibis, near the mountain called Sigoron.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 33:6
verses.text: When they first entered upon the philosophic career, they were denominated shepherds, because they had no houses, ate neither bread nor meat, and drank no wine; but dwelt constantly on the mountains, and passed their time in praising God by prayers and hymns, according to the law of the Church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 33:7
verses.text: At the usual hours of meals, they each took a sickle, and went to the mountain to cut some grass on the mountains, as though they were flocks in pasture; and this served for their repast.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 33:8
verses.text: Such was their course of philosophy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 33:9
verses.text: Eusebius voluntarily shut himself up in a cell to philosophize, near Carrae.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 33:10
verses.text: Protogenes dwelt in the same locality, and ruled the church there after Vitus who was then bishop.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 33:11
verses.text: This is the celebrated Vitus of whom they say that when the Emperor Constantine first saw him, he confessed that God had frequently shown this man in appearances to him and enjoined him to obey implicitly what he should say.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 33:12
verses.text: Aones had a monastery in Phadana; this was the spot where Jacob, the grandson of Abraham, on his journey from Palestine, met the damsel whom he afterwards married, and where he rolled away the stone, that her flock might drink of the water of the well.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 33:13
verses.text: It is said that Aones was the first who introduced the life apart from all men, and the severe philosophy into Syria, just as it was first introduced by Antony into Egypt.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIV.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:2
verses.text: —Monks of Edessa: Julianus, Ephraim Syrus, Barus, and Eulogius; Further, the Monks of Coele-Syria: Valentinus, Theodore, Merosas, Bassus, Bassonius; and the Holy Men of Galatia and Cappadocia, and Elsewhere; why those Saints until recently were Long-Lived.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:3
verses.text: Gaddanas and Azizus dwelt with Aones, and emulated his virtues.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:4
verses.text: Ephraim the Syrian, who was an historian, and has been noticed  in our own recital of events under the reign of Constantius, was the most renowned philosopher in this time, together with Julian, in the neighborhood of Edessa and its adjacent regions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:5
verses.text: Barses  and Eulogius were both, at a later period than that to which we are referring, ordained bishops, but not of any city; for the title was merely an honorary one, conferred on them as a compensation for their excellent conduct; and they were ordained in their own monasteries.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:6
verses.text: Lazarus, to whom we have already alluded, was ordained bishop in the same manner.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:7
verses.text: Such were the most celebrated philosophers of asceticism who flourished in Syria, Persia, and the neighboring countries, so far, at least, as I have been able to ascertain.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:8
verses.text: The course common to all, so to speak, consisted in diligent attention to the state of the soul, which by means of fasting, prayer, and hymns to God, they kept in constant preparation to quit the things of this world.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:9
verses.text: They devoted the greater part of their time to these holy exercises, and they wholly despised worldly possessions, temporal affairs, and the ease and adornment of the body.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:10
verses.text: Some of the monks carried their self-denial to an extraordinary height.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:11
verses.text: Battheus, for instance, by excessive abstinence and fasting, had worms crawl from his teeth; Halas, again, had not tasted bread for eighty years; and Heliodorus passed many nights without yielding to sleep, and added thereto seven days of fasting.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:12
verses.text: Although Coele-Syria and Upper Syria, with the exception of the city of Antioch, was slowly converted to Christianity, it was not lacking in ecclesiastical philosophers, whose conduct appeared the more heroic from their having to encounter the enmity and hatred of the inhabitants of the place.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:13
verses.text: And they nobly refrained from resistance, or resorting to the law, but spiritedly endured the insults and blows inflicted by the pagans.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:14
verses.text: Such, I found, was the course pursued by Valentian, who, according to some accounts, was born at Emesa, but according to others, at Arethusa.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:15
verses.text: Another individual of the same name distinguished himself by similar conduct, as likewise Theodore.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:16
verses.text: Both were from Titti, which is of the nome of the Apameans; not less distinguished were Marosas, a native of Nechilis, Bassus, Bassones, and Paul.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:17
verses.text: This latter was from the village of Telmison.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:18
verses.text: He rounded many communities in many places, and introduced the method essential to the knowledge of philosophy, and finally established the greatest and most distinguished community of monks in a place called Jugatum.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:19
verses.text: Here, after a long and honorable life, he died, and was interred.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:20
verses.text: Some of the monks who have practiced philosophy in a distinguished and divine way have survived to our own days; indeed, most of those to whom allusion has been made enjoyed a very long term of existence; and I am convinced that God added to the length of their days for the express purpose of furthering the interests of religion.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:21
verses.text: They were instrumental in leading nearly the whole Syrian nation, and most of the Persians and Saracens, to the proper religion, and caused them to cease from paganism.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:22
verses.text: After beginning the monastic philosophy there, they brought forward many like themselves.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:23
verses.text: I suppose that Galatia, Cappadocia, and the neighboring provinces contained many other ecclesiastical philosophers at that time, for these regions formerly had zealously embraced our doctrine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:24
verses.text: These monks, for the most part, dwelt in communities in cities and villages, for they did not habituate themselves to the tradition of their predecessors.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:25
verses.text: The severity of the winter, which is always a natural feature of that country, would probably make a hermit life impracticable.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:26
verses.text: Leontius and Prapidius were, I understand, the most celebrated of these monks.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:27
verses.text: The former afterwards administered the church of Ancyra, and the latter, a man of very advanced age, performed the episcopal functions in several villages.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:28
verses.text: He also presided over the Basileias, the most celebrated hospice for the poor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 34:29
verses.text: It was established by Basil, bishop of Caesarea, from whom it received its name in the beginning, and retains it until to-day.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXV.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:2
verses.text: —The Wooden Tripod and the Succession of the Emperor, through a Knowledge of its Letters.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:3
verses.text: Destruction of the Philosophers; Astronomy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:4
verses.text: Such is the information which I have been enabled to collect concerning the ecclesiastical philosophers of that time.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:5
verses.text: As to the pagans, they were nearly all exterminated about the period to which we have been referring.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:6
verses.text: Some among them, who were reputed to excel in philosophy, and who viewed with extreme displeasure the progress of the Christian religion, were devising who would be the successor of Valens on the throne of the Roman Empire, and resorted to every variety of mantic art for the purpose of attaining this insight into futurity.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:7
verses.text: After various incantations, they constructed a tripod of laurel wood, and they wound up with the invocations and words to which they are accustomed; so that the name of the emperor might be shown by the collection of letters which were indicated, letter by letter, through the machinery of the tripod and the prophecy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:8
verses.text: They were gaping with open mouth for Theodore, a man who held a distinguished military appointment in the palace.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:9
verses.text: He was a pagan and a learned man.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:10
verses.text: The disposition of the letters, coming as far as the delta of his name, deceived the philosophers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:11
verses.text: They hence expected that Theodore would very soon be the emperor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:12
verses.text: When their undertaking was informed upon, Valens was as unbearably incensed, as if a conspiracy had been formed against his safety.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:13
verses.text: Therefore all were arrested; Theodore and the constructors of the tripod were commanded to be put to death, some with fire, others with the sword.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:14
verses.text: Likewise for the same reason the most brilliant philosophers of the empire were slain; since the wrath of the emperor was unchecked, the death penalty advanced even to those who were not philosophers, but who wore garments similar to theirs; hence those who applied themselves to other pursuits would not clothe themselves with the crocotium or tribonium, on account of the suspicion and fear of danger, so that they might not seem to be pursuing magic and sorcery.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:15
verses.text: I do not in the least think that the emperor will be more blamed by right-thinking people for such wrath and cruelty than the philosophers, for their rashness and their unphilosophical undertaking.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:16
verses.text: The emperor, absurdly supposing that he could put his successor to death, spared neither those who had prophesied nor the subject of their prophecy, as they say he did not spare those who bore the same name of Theodore,—and some were men of distinction,—whether they were precisely the same or similar in beginning with θ and ending with δ.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:17
verses.text: The philosophers, on the other hand, acted as if the deposition and restoration of emperors had depended solely on them; for if the imperial succession was to be considered dependent on the arrangement of the stars, what was requisite but to await the accession of the future emperor, whoever he might be? or if the succession was regarded as dependent on the will of God, what right had man to meddle? For it is not the function of human foreknowledge or zeal to understand God's thought; nor if it were right, would it be well for men, even if they be the wisest of all, to think that they can plan better than God.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 35:18
verses.text: If it were merely from rash curiosity to discern the things of futurity that they showed such lack of judgment as to be ready to be caught in danger, and to despise the laws anciently established among the Romans, and at a time when it was not dangerous to conduct pagan worship and to sacrifice; in this they thought differently from Socrates; for when unjustly condemned to drink poison, he refused to save himself by violating the laws in which he had been born and educated, nor would he escape from prison, although it was in his power to do so.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVI.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:2
verses.text: —Expedition against the Sarmatians; Death of Valentinian in Rome; Valentinian the Younger proclaimed; Persecution of the Priests; Oration of the Philosopher Themistius, on account of which Valens was disposed to treat those who differed from him more Humanely.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:3
verses.text: Such subjects as the above, however, are best left to the examination and decision of individual judgment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:4
verses.text: The Sarmatians  having invaded the western parts of the empire, Valentinian levied an army to oppose them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:5
verses.text: As soon, however, as they heard of the number and strength of the troops raised against them, they sent an embassy to solicit peace.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:6
verses.text: When the ambassadors were ushered into the presence of Valentinian, he asked them whether all the Sarmatians were similar to them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:7
verses.text: On their replying that the principal men of the nation had been selected to form the embassy, the emperor exclaimed, in great fury, "A terrible thing do our subjects endure, and a calamity is surrounding the Roman government, if the Sarmatians, a barbarous race, of whom these are your best men, do not love to abide by themselves, but are emboldened to invade my government, and presume to make war at all against the Romans".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:8
verses.text: He spoke in this strain for some time in a very high pitch of voice, and his rage was so violent and so unbounded, that at length he burst simultaneously a blood-vessel and an artery.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:9
verses.text: He lost, in consequence, a great quantity of blood, and expired soon after in a fortress of Gaul.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:10
verses.text: He was about fifty-four years of age, and had, during thirteen years, guided the reins of government with good results and much distinction.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:11
verses.text: Six days after his death his youngest son, who bore the same name as himself, was proclaimed emperor by the soldiers; and soon afterwards Valens and Gratian, his brother, formally assented to this election, although they were at first irritated at the soldiers having transferred the symbols of government to him without their previous consent.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:12
verses.text: During this period Valens had fixed his residence at Antioch in Syria, and became more hostile to those who differed from him in opinion concerning the divine nature, and he vexed them more severely and persecuted them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:13
verses.text: The philosopher Themistius pronounced an oration in his presence, in which he admonished him that he ought not to wonder at the dissension concerning ecclesiastical doctrines, for it was more moderate and less than among the pagans, for the opinions among them are multiform; and that, in the number of dogmas leading to perpetual disputes, necessarily the difference about them makes more contentions and discussions; and accordingly it might probably be pleasing to God not to be so easily known, and to have a divergence of opinion, so that each might fear Him the rather, since an accurate knowledge of Him is so unattainable.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 36:14
verses.text: And in the attempt to summarize this vastness, one would tend to conclude how great He is and how good He is.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:2
verses.text: —Concerning the Barbarians beyond the Danube, who were driven out by the Huns, and advanced to the Romans, and their Conversion to Christianity; Ulphilas and Athanarichus; Occurrences between them; whence the Goths received Arianism.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:3
verses.text: This remarkable oration of Themistius disposed the emperor to be somewhat more humane, and the punishments became in consequence less severe than before.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:4
verses.text: He would not have wholly withdrawn his wrath from the priests unless the anxieties of public affairs had supervened, and not permitted him to pursue them further.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:5
verses.text: For the Goths, who inhabited the regions beyond the Ister, and had conquered other barbarians, having been vanquished and driven from their country by the Huns, had passed over into the Roman boundaries.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:6
verses.text: The Huns, it is said, were unknown to the Thracians of the Ister and the Goths before this period; for though they were dwelling secretly near to one another, a lake of vast extent was between them, and the inhabitants on each side of the lake respectively imagined that their own country was situated at the extremity of the earth, and that there was nothing beyond them but the sea and water.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:7
verses.text: It so happened, however, that an ox, tormented by insects, plunged into the lake, and was pursued by the herdsman; who, perceiving for the first time that the opposite bank was inhabited, made known the circumstance to his fellow-tribesmen.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:8
verses.text: Some, however, relate that a stag was fleeing, and showed some of the hunters who were of the race of the Huns the way which was concealed superficially by the water.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:9
verses.text: On arriving at the opposite bank, the hunters were struck with the beauty of the country, the serenity of the air, and the adaptedness for cultivation; and they reported what they had seen to their king.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:10
verses.text: The Huns then made an attempt to attack the Goths with a few soldiers; but they afterwards raised a powerful army, conquered the Goths in battle, and took possession of their whole country.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:11
verses.text: The vanquished nation, being pursued by their enemies, crossed over into the Roman territories.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:12
verses.text: They passed over the river, and dispatched an embassy to the emperor, assuring him of their co-operation in any warfare in which he might engage, provided that he would assign a portion of land for them to inhabit.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:13
verses.text: Ulphilas, the bishop of the nation, was the chief of the embassy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:14
verses.text: The object of his embassy was fully accomplished, and the Goths were permitted to take up their abode in Thrace.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:15
verses.text: Soon after contentions broke out among them, which led to their division into two parts, one of which was headed by Athanaric, and the other by Phritigernes.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:16
verses.text: They took up arms against each other, and Phritigernes was vanquished, and implored the assistance of the Romans.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:17
verses.text: The emperor having commanded the troops in Thrace to assist and to ally with him, a second battle was fought, and Athanaric and his party were put to flight.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:18
verses.text: In acknowledgment of the timely succor afforded by Valens, and in proof of his fidelity to the Romans, Phritigernes embraced the religion of the emperor, and persuaded the barbarians over whom he ruled to follow his example.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:19
verses.text: It does not, however, appear to me that this is the only reason that can be advanced to account for the Goths having retained, even to the present day, the tenets of Arianism.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:20
verses.text: For Ulphilas, their bishop, originally held no opinions at variance with those of the Catholic Church; for during the reign of Constantius, though he took part, as I am convinced, from thoughtlessness, at the council of Constantinople, in conjunction with Eudoxius and Acacius, yet he did not swerve from the doctrines of the Nicaean council.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:21
verses.text: He afterwards, it appears, returned to Constantinople, and, it is said, entered into disputations on doctrinal topics with the chiefs of the Arian faction; and they promised to lay his requests before the emperor, and forward the object of his embassy, if he would conform to their opinions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:22
verses.text: Compelled by the urgency of the occasion, or, possibly, thinking that it was better to hold such views concerning the Divine nature, Ulphilas entered into communion with the Arians, and separated himself and his whole nation from all connection with the Catholic Church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:23
verses.text: For as he had instructed the Goths in the elements of religion, and through him they shared in a gentler mode of life, they placed the most implicit confidence in his directions, and were firmly convinced that he could neither do nor say anything that was evil.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:24
verses.text: He had, in fact, given many signal proofs of the greatness of his virtue.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:25
verses.text: He had exposed himself to innumerable perils in defense of the faith, during the period that the aforesaid barbarians were given to pagan worship.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:26
verses.text: He taught them the use of letters, and translated the Sacred Scriptures into their own language.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:27
verses.text: It was on this account, that the barbarians on the banks of the Ister followed the tenets of Arius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:28
verses.text: At the same period, there were many of the subjects of Phritigernes who testified to Christ, and were martyred.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:29
verses.text: Athanaric resented that his subjects had become Christian under the persuasion of Ulphilas; and because they had abandoned the cult of their fathers, he subjected many individuals to many punishments; some he put to death after they had been dragged before tribunals and had nobly confessed the doctrine, and others were slain without being permitted to utter a single word in their own defense.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:30
verses.text: It is said that the officers appointed by Athanaric to execute his cruel mandates, caused a statue to be constructed, which they placed on a chariot, and had it conveyed to the tents of those who were suspected of having embraced Christianity, and who were therefore commanded to worship the statue and offer sacrifice; if they refused to do so, the men and the tents were burnt together.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:31
verses.text: But I have heard that an outrage of still greater atrocity was perpetrated at this period.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:32
verses.text: Many refused to obey those who were compelling them by force to sacrifice.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:33
verses.text: Among them were men and women; of the latter some were leading their little children, others were nourishing their new-born infants at the breast; they fled to their church, which was a tent.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:34
verses.text: The pagans set fire to it, and all were destroyed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:35
verses.text: The Goths were not long in making peace among themselves; and in unreasonable excitement, they then began to ravage Thrace and to pillage the cities and villages.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:36
verses.text: Valens, on inquiry, learned by experiment how great a mistake he had made; for he had calculated that the Goths would always be useful to the empire and formidable to its enemies, and had therefore neglected the reinforcement of the Roman ranks.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:37
verses.text: He had taken gold from the cities and villages under the Romans, instead of the usual complement of men for the military service.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:38
verses.text: On his expectation being thus frustrated, he quitted Antioch and hastened to Constantinople.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:39
verses.text: Hence the persecution which he had been carrying on against Christians differing in opinion from himself, had a truce.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 37:40
verses.text: Euzoïus, president of the Arians, died, and Dorotheus was proposed for his government.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVIII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:2
verses.text: —Concerning Mania, the Phylarch of the Saracens.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:3
verses.text: When the Treaty with the Romans was dissolved, Moses, their Bishop, who had been ordained by the Christians, renewed it.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:4
verses.text: Narrative concerning the Ishmaelites and the Saracens, and their Goods; and how they began to be Christianized through Zocomus, Their Phylarch.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:5
verses.text: About this period the king of the Saracens died,  and the peace which had previously existed between that nation and the Romans was dissolved.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:6
verses.text: Mania,  the widow of the late monarch, after attaining to the government of her race, led her troops into Phoenicia and Palestine, as far as the regions of Egypt lying to the left of those who sail towards the source of the Nile, and which are generally denominated Arabia.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:7
verses.text: This war was by no means a contemptible one, although conducted by a woman.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:8
verses.text: The Romans, it is said, considered it so arduous and so perilous, that the general of the Phoenician troops applied for assistance to the general of the entire cavalry and infantry of the East.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:9
verses.text: This latter ridiculed the summons, and undertook to give battle alone.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:10
verses.text: He accordingly attacked Mania, who commanded her own troops in person; and he was rescued with difficulty by the general of the troops of Palestine and Phoenicia.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:11
verses.text: Perceiving the extremity of the danger, this general deemed it unnecessary to obey the orders he had received to keep aloof from the combat; he therefore rushed upon the barbarians, and furnished his superior an opportunity for safe retreat, while he himself yielded ground and shot at those who fled, and beat off with his arrows the enemies who were pressing upon him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:12
verses.text: This occurrence is still held in remembrance among the people of the country, and is celebrated in songs by the Saracens.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:13
verses.text: As the war was still pursued with vigor, the Romans found it necessary to send an embassy to Mania to solicit peace.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:14
verses.text: It is said that she refused to comply with the request of the embassy, unless consent were given for the ordination of a certain man named Moses, who practiced philosophy in a neighboring desert, as bishop over her subjects.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:15
verses.text: This Moses was a man of virtuous life, and noted for performing the divine and miraculous signs.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:16
verses.text: On these conditions being announced to the emperor, the chiefs of the army were commanded to seize Moses, and conduct him to Lucius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:17
verses.text: The monk exclaimed, in the presence of the rulers and the assembled people, "I am not worthy of the honor of bearing the name and dignity of chief priest; but if, notwithstanding my unworthiness God destines me to this office, I take Him to witness who created the heavens and the earth, that I will not be ordained by the imposition of the hands of Lucius, which are defiled with the blood of holy men".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:18
verses.text: Lucius immediately rejoined, "If you are unacquainted with the nature of my creed, you do wrong in judging me before you are in possession of all the circumstances of the case.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:19
verses.text: If you have been prejudiced by the calumnies that have been circulated against me, at least allow me to declare to you what are my sentiments; and do you be the judge of them".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:20
verses.text: "Your creed is already well known to me," replied Moses; "and its nature is testified by bishops, presbyters, and deacons, who are suffering grievously in exile, and the mines.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:21
verses.text: It is clear that your sentiments are opposed to the faith of Christ, and to all orthodox doctrines concerning the Godhead".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:22
verses.text: Having again protested, upon oath, that he would not receive ordination from them, he went to the Saracens.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:23
verses.text: He reconciled them to the Romans, and converted many to Christianity, and passed his life among them as a priest, although he found few who shared in his belief.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:24
verses.text: This is the tribe which took its origin and had its name from Ishmael, the son of Abraham; and the ancients called them Ishmaelites after their progenitor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:25
verses.text: As their mother Hagar was a slave, they afterwards, to conceal the opprobrium of their origin, assumed the name of Saracens, as if they were descended from Sara, the wife of Abraham.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:26
verses.text: Such being their origin, they practice circumcision like the Jews, refrain from the use of pork, and observe many other Jewish rites and customs.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:27
verses.text: If, indeed, they deviate in any respect from the observances of that nation, it must be ascribed to the lapse of time, and to their intercourse with the neighboring nations.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:28
verses.text: Moses, who lived many centuries after Abraham, only legislated for those whom he led out of Egypt.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:29
verses.text: The inhabitants of the neighboring countries, being strongly addicted to superstition, probably soon corrupted the laws imposed upon them by their forefather Ishmael.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:30
verses.text: The ancient Hebrews had their community life under this law only, using therefore unwritten customs, before the Mosaic legislation.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:31
verses.text: These people certainly served the same gods as the neighboring nations, honoring and naming them similarly, so that by this likeness with their forefathers in religion, there is evidenced their departure from the laws of their forefathers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:32
verses.text: As is usual, in the lapse of time, their ancient customs fell into oblivion, and other practices gradually got the precedence among them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:33
verses.text: Some of their tribe afterwards happening to come in contact with the Jews, gathered from them the facts of their true origin, returned to their kinsmen, and inclined to the Hebrew customs and laws.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:34
verses.text: From that time on, until now, many of them regulate their lives according to the Jewish precepts.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:35
verses.text: Some of the Saracens were converted to Christianity not long before the present reign.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:36
verses.text: They shared in the faith of Christ by intercourse with the priests and monks who dwelt near them, and practiced philosophy in the neighboring deserts, and who were distinguished by the excellence of their life, and by their miraculous works.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:37
verses.text: It is said that a whole tribe, and Zocomus, their chief, were converted to Christianity and baptized about this period, under the following circumstances: Zocomus was childless, and went to a certain monk of great celebrity to complain to him of this calamity; for among the Saracens, and I believe other barbarian nations, it was accounted of great importance to have children.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:38
verses.text: The monk desired Zocomus to be of good cheer, engaged in prayer on his behalf, and sent him away with the promise that if he would believe in Christ, he would have a son.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:39
verses.text: When this promise was confirmed by God, and when a son was born to him, Zocomus was initiated, and all his subjects with him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:40
verses.text: From that period this tribe was peculiarly fortunate, and became strong in point of number, and formidable to the Persians as well as to the other Saracens.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 38:41
verses.text: Such are the details that I have been enabled to collect concerning the conversion of the Saracens and their first bishop.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 39:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIX.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 39:2
verses.text: —Peter, having returned from Rome, regains the Churches of Egypt, after Lucius had given way; Expedition of Valens into the West against the Scythians.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 39:3
verses.text: Those in every city who maintained the Nicene doctrine now began to take courage, and more particularly the inhabitants of Alexandria in Egypt.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 39:4
verses.text: Peter  had returned thither from Rome with a letter from Damasus, confirmatory of the tenets of Nicaea and of his own ordination; and he was installed in the government of the churches in the place of Lucius, who sailed away to Constantinople after his eviction.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 39:5
verses.text: The Emperor Valens very naturally was so distracted by other affairs, that he had no leisure to attend to these transactions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 39:6
verses.text: He had no sooner arrived at Constantinople than he incurred the suspicion and hatred of the people.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 39:7
verses.text: The barbarians were pillaging Thrace, and were even advancing to the very suburbs, and attempted to make an assault on the very walls, with no one to hinder them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 39:8
verses.text: The city was indignant at this inertness; and the people even charged the emperor with being a party to their attack, because he did not sally forth, but delayed offering battle.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 39:9
verses.text: At length, when he was present at the sports of the Hippodrome, the people openly and loudly accused him of neglecting the affairs of the state, and demanded arms that they might fight in their own defense.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 39:10
verses.text: Valens, offended at these reproaches, immediately undertook an expedition against the barbarians; but he threatened to punish the insolence of the people on his return, and also to take vengeance on them for having formerly supported the tyrant Procopius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:1
verses.text: Chapter XL.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:2
verses.text: —Saint Isaac, the Monk, predicts the Death of Valens.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:3
verses.text: Valens in his Flight enters a Chaff-House, is consumed, and so yields up his Life.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:4
verses.text: When Valens was on the point of departing from Constantinople,  Isaac, a monk of great virtue, who feared no danger in the cause of God, presented himself before him, and addressed him in the following words: "Give back, O emperor, to the orthodox, and to those who maintain the Nicene doctrines, the churches of which you have deprived them, and the victory will be yours".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:5
verses.text: The emperor was offended at this act of boldness, and commanded that Isaac should be arrested and kept in chains until his return, when he meant to bring him to justice for his temerity.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:6
verses.text: Isaac, however, replied, "You will not return unless you restore the churches".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:7
verses.text: And so in fact it came to pass.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:8
verses.text: For when Valens marched out with his army, the Goths retreated while pursued.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:9
verses.text: In his advances he passed by Thrace, and came to Adrianople.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:10
verses.text: When at not great distance from the barbarians, he found them encamped in a secure position; and yet he had the rashness to attack them before he had arranged his own legions in proper order.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:11
verses.text: His cavalry was dispersed, his infantry compelled to retreat; and, pursued by the enemy, he dismounted from his horse, and with a few attendants entered into a small house or tower, where he secreted himself.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:12
verses.text: The barbarians were in full pursuit, and went beyond the tower, not suspecting that he had selected it for his place of concealment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:13
verses.text: As the last detachment of the barbarians was passing by the tower, the attendants of the emperor let fly a volley of arrows from their covert, which immediately led to the exclamation that Valens was concealed within the building.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:14
verses.text: Those who were a little in advance heard this exclamation, and made known the news with a shout to those companions who were in advance of them; and thus the news was conveyed till it reached the detachments which were foremost in the pursuit.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:15
verses.text: They returned, and encompassed the tower.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:16
verses.text: They collected vast quantities of wood from the country around, which they piled up against the tower, and finally set fire to the mass.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:17
verses.text: A wind which had happened to arise favored the progress of the conflagration; and in a short period the tower, with all that it contained, including the emperor and his attendants, was utterly destroyed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:18
verses.text: Valens was fifty years of age.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VI 40:19
verses.text: He had reigned thirteen years conjointly with his brother, and three by himself.
